column1: this saw is hard to get used to . it has a spring loaded guard that you need to hold a trigger to release it , while using the saw you need to push down all the way , and forward . this combination is actually more dangerous than having the guard there in the first place . because you have to focus pushing downward , it 's easy to slip out of the cut , i 'm temped to pull out one of those wheels and replace it with a thumb screw.its also uncomfortable to hold , the device flares out and digs into your hand , something else i have to modify.and the laser is battery operated , leave it on and it dies . the laser is also far too bright , i ca n't see the pencil line and for the most part is a useless feature since it really only works well for long things , and if i were cutting something long , i would use a real saw . the saw is strong enough to push through 3/4 & # 34 ; plywood and the small size makes it easy for an afternoon job , or a plunge cut . all the dust shoots out the bottom of the cut . because you can only use one hand to use it , there is still a chance you 'll cut a thumb off if your holding the board in place.i love the bag , i wish all tools came in bags . it 's about the size of a shoe box , and you can put other tools in there . right now i have that and a rotozip , seems like a good combo . i wish the bag has straps for a shoulder though , it does n't even have rings for one . but it 's sort of a bonus so i should n't complain.it was between this one and the dremel max thing , i did n't get dremel due to the terrible blade design they had , grinding wood will just start fires . this saw actually has a blade.oh and while small , and seemingly perfect for cutting things like lattice or thin stock . you still need to put it on a table , because of that darn guard , pushing it down and forward is too hard . so the dremel would win cutting that kind of stock .

Works as advertised except that laser switch will not stay on . Especially useful and fast for cross cutting using a speed square . Takes a few minutes to adjust to holding switch while pressing blade down . Rockwell should sell individual blade types separately instead of in combination .

The Good : Easily adjustable.Cuts like a dream through intended materials.Has shown itself to be durable and well made.The Bad : The laser on mine is basically useless ( unless cutting in the dark , maybe ) , and does n't seem to be aligned properly.Bottom Line : Recommended , for specific materials and tasks , finishing work .

Received the Rockwell RK3440K VersaCut Circular Saw as a Christmas gift last year . Really had no idea how I 'd use the tool since I have a circular saw already . Let me tell you , my standard circular saw collects dust now . The VersaCut is so easy compact and easy to use . The laser and edge guide provide nice straight cuts . The depth control and retractable blade keeps it safe . I 'm able to make cuts at all angles and positions . This is one of the best , most used tools in my house ! My only tips are:1 . Make sure your work surface is stable . Exposing the blade takes a fairly significant amount of pressure.2 . Do n't forget to turn off the laser !
The quality of this product is amazing , it was a gift for my Father . he loves it , his only complaint is the spring retention on the metal plate is VERY stiff and he wishes he could adjust it .

Cut some pressure treated 4x4 's , did n't even slow the versa cut down . I 've not tried it on metal or brick ... .maybe never will , it just nice to use for small jobs rather bringing out a full size circular saw or table saw . I use to use a jig saw for small cuts ... .this leaves a better cut ... .if it a straight line your needing .
Age and health was severely cramping my ability to weild my regular circular saw , and this was the perfect saw for weight , ease , and for the type of cuts I was now making .
This is a nice saw . Easy to use and is a great asset to my tools . Great for jobs in tight corners

I am a professional contractor and had no idea that I needed one of these until I tried one . I can cut tile , grout , drywall , plywood , siding , shingles , hardie-backer , etc.- all while using a vacuum attachment that actually works ! This is a very important aspect of a renovator 's livelihood if you are in a different customer 's house everyday . This tool cuts clean with a deapth adjustment and keeps the home clean for the homeowner ( and me ) . The compact size lets me get into smaller areas . Best of all , I do n't need to drag out the worm drive for cuts under an inch thick anymore ! The laser button needs to be thought-out better ( location ) but , it has no effect on the performance.Best thing since my Fien Multi-tool .
I love the size of the Saw and the way it can cut along a line without messing up like a heavy saw has a tendency to be hard to follow a cut line.Timothy the tool man

This is my first Rockwell tool . My first impression is that it was made well and was a good quality tool . We put it right to work on several flood restoration projects cutting out waterlogged drywall . Setting the blade for the desired depth of cut was fast and easy . The plunge cut blade hits the the set depth and you cut away . With a vacuum hooked up there was virtually no dust from the drywall . The laser line seems to work fine but we snapped chalk lines and followed them as you normally would with any circular saw . Although we purchased this saw specifically for cutting out drywall , I 'm confident it would work well in other limited cutting applications .

While I think Rockwell has an excellent idea going , I think they missed the boat on ergonomics . For one , this machine is not well balanced , and consequently creates fatigue . The safety features that are there to prevent the blade from being exposed requires that one lever first be pressed and released , before the power button can be turned on , and at the same time one needs to keep pressure on the saw to keep it plunged . My wrist started to hurt within 5 minutes of using the saw , and I find it a major annoyance for an otherwise well designed machine . As the blades start to dull , further pressure is required to keep the saw in contact with the work . I resorted to wedging a small piece of wood in the sliding mechanism to keep the saw plunged , although I certainly do n't advocate that anybody else do this . I use an acrylic base and a guide , so I 'm not overly concerned if the saw kicks back . The very small diameter blade tends to prevent kickbacks , but it is possible.My other complaint about this saw is that the blade is on the left-hand side of the base , as opposed to the right . Again , for right-handed people this is out of balance . If you need to trim say a half or three quarters of an inch off a board , most of the weight of the machine is not supported . The old worm drive skill saws were like this and I always hated that design . If you 're left-handed , you will probably love it ; ) The plus side is it 's easier to guide/see the blade . Most people will probably find this feature a plus , but I do n't like it.The saw seems to have plenty of power for maximum depth of cut , although I have not tried going through any hardwood as of yet , just plywood . I did have some issues with chipping on plywood with the supplied 24 tooth blade . The 40 tooth metal Blade gives cleaner crosscuts , but dulls quite quickly . I would like to see a 32 or 40 tooth wood blade become available . This is the only saw I can think of that has one , and only one option for a carbide tipped blade . What woodworker only uses one blade ? Give us some options Rockwell ! The ability to use a vacuum is absolutely wonderful , and the saw feels very safe on small pieces of lumber . There are many times I have wished for a small saw like this , so many of its features are welcome . I just wish they designed it like a more traditional circular saw . Makita , Dewalt and others have more traditional designs in their plunge saws .

Great little saw for those small jobs . The locking nut was on so tight that I needed a socket wrench and extra muscle to loosen it . I took advantage of an Amazon Warehouse Deal to get it cheaper than Retail . The laser alignment is the first one I 've seen that is accurate to where the blade runs ( and not offset ) . And the laser is quite strong , too .

Superb light output and these can be dimmed extremely well down to near zero without flickering on an X10 style remote light control system . I think the warm white works better in living room and entertainment room areas with earth tone colors than the blue-ish light output from the pure white 5100K color temperature bulbs .

I placed these LED lights ( warm white ) in the ceiling of an entryway to the garage . I was always turning these lights OFF for others when the area was not in use . When I turned ON the new LED lights , I thought my wife would be unhappy with the appearance ; however , I surprisingly heard her say , `` Oh , I like these ! '' So , now using only 10 % of the electricity to produce nearly as much light , I do not mind the family leaving the lights ON in this entry area . Also , the old , original dimmer works just fine , so there is no need to pay double for a special dimmer . The original dimmer dims the LED lights from full-bright down to about one-third-bright , which is just fine . The only getting use to is the one-second delay when turning these LED lights ON .

I bought a bunch of these for my home . I put them in to recessed canned lighting on the ceiling . The light output is nice in quantity and quality of the cool white . I have tried 2 other brands of the same type of lamp , maxximastyle and ecosmart . These LEDwholesalers are better than those in both quality and price . Cheers .
Work very well on our porch . Dimmable and provide much more light than I expected . LEDs are pricey , but we bought six for the porch and they light it very well .

I bought these to replace the outdoor floodlight I currently have . Fist , I happen to prefer the cooler while light over the warm ( or more yellow ) light that a halogen or incandescent will give . This is a matter of taste and if you do n't like the cool light , do not get these , you wo n't like it . However if you can live with it , they flood very nicely and light a wide area . I use these in light with motion sensor lights and they light up fast . Now for the money saving part . My house and yard are ringed with these lights and when I take my dogs outside to work them , they can turn them all on in no time . That 's over 1100 watts of conventional halogen lighting . With these and other lighting systems , I am down to under 200 watts . I 'm saving close to $ 50 , thanks to my conversion . I figure after about 10 months , they will have paid for themselves and the savings is free and clear .

As other reviewers here mentioned , these LED bulbs are super bright ... daylight bright . Turns night into day ! I use these on my motion-sensor system . They exhibit no visible borders ( the circular pattern you 'd see with spotlights ) like the previous halogen bulbs I 've used . The spread patterns are wide . Just be aware you 're that these are daylight bulbs and you should not be disappointed . Lowes carry several brands ( Sylvania 's ? ) of these LED style but cost 10-15 dollars more .

Two flood lights at my stairs are rather difficult to access . I decided to put LED lights there so that I do n't need to replace them that often.I 'm very happy with this LED light . It is very bright . It looks like it is very well constructed . It is much heavier than a regular or CFL light bulb , but I do n't have any problem with that .
This lamp will last you a very long time and it 's brighter than any other lamp I have ever seen before . It will also save you plenty of money in your light bill .

I tested these bulbs against the Phillips 15Watt , G7 18Watt ( 1200 Lumens ) , and Fiet 18 Watt ( 1000 lumens ) . For area coverage brightness these were the best . It was made to RoHS specs . It 's 2 watts more , but the price was also the best bang per buck . The G7 was a warmer yellow spot light , the Fiet was on par with the phillips but still a spot light . The only bad thing about this light is that it 's not suitable for outdoors as indicated on the box , the G7 , Phillips , and Fiet were .

We purchased this bulb to test it in a recessed can on an enclosed porch . CFLs do not like cold temperatures , do n't dim well , and of course the traditional incandescent bulbs are going the way of the dodos . So maybe LEDs will provide the proverbial light at the end of this tunnel our congress critters made for us.My `` cans '' are made for par30s , and I needed a `` socket extender '' to make this par38 fit , but the light it produces is MUCH more than the par30 LED I tested . Hence it is worth futzing with the socket extender- I am very impressed with the amount of light . The light is much brighter and whiter than the 45 watt incandescent par30 it is replacing . To my eye it is about the color of sunlight , not as yellow as most lighting . The dimming works well , without the change in light color which happens with incandescent bulbs . At minimum on the dimmer the LED light is still producing some light , while the incandescent is completely dark . I do n't mind this , but YMMV.This bulb has a fairly wide angle of illumination , good for recessed lighting and probably good for a floodlight as well . Not sure if it can handle weather though.The only downside is the cost and the relatively untried technology . I expect the cost to continue to drop , and these `` may '' be cost-effective , even at $ 50 a bulb . I have not found the CFLs to live up to the hype in terms of life span , perhaps the LEDs may do better . The estimates raise the philosophical question of why I would want to buy a light bulb that will last longer than my house . They are certainly efficient , but at the rate I am using this bulb ( 2 or 3 hours , maybe 3 nights a week ) , it will take me about 100 years to report on the accuracy of the 20,000 to 50,000 hour life expectancy . Stay tuned ! The bottom line is that we like this light a lot .

I previously purchased , and reviewed , the similar LED floodlight with a more industrial lighting color . When my spouse complained they looked too much like an office or a shopping mall , I decided to try these in hopes I could still get efficient lighting in the PAR38 form-factor . Well , great choice . I replaced the other bulbs and the effect is dramatic . I 'm going to be using these two or three at a time ( they are pricey ) to replace all the interior floodlights as the existing bulbs come to end of life , if not before.So far , I find this brand a higher quality than other brands I 've purchased , and reviewed , in the past . They are better made ( more physically sturdy ) , better packaged ( a stronger , better labeled box ) and easier to install ( the threaded portion is cleaner and smoother and screws in without any binding ) .They are n't cheap and they are n't the cheapest , but they are the best VALUE that I 've found so far in the still-not-cheap LED bulbs.Sometimes shipping is labeled as free , as in `` Free shipping when purchased from LEDwholesalers '' , but the charge is up to $ 11.60 to ship , so be cautious about what you are doing here .

Installation was pretty easy , but if you do n't know what you are doing in a breaker box , I 'd suggest getting some assistance.The device pretty much just sits there and looks at me with its green glowing eyes . With any luck it is actually doing something ! I really do n't know the science behind it , but figured it was pretty cheap insurance to help protect other electronics in the house from a surge .

I 've had more than my share of damage of my electronics due to thunder storms . I bought two of these and installed them according to the instructions and solved all my problems . Good product fair price . I 'm delighted .

This thing is simple to install . It replaced a 20-Amp 2 Pole 240-Volt Circuit Breaker . Once I turned the surge protector ` s breakers on , two built-in green lights came on indicating circuit protection . This is an excellent choice over having many surge protector strips all around the house . However , like any other surge protector , one must really hope to never have to find out if it really works ... or not.One drawback is that it does n't protect cable TV as cable or satellite signal is sent through a coaxial cable independent of the electric wiring . For that you may want to install a surge protector like theIntermatic IG1300-2T-1C3 120/240 VAC Single Phase Type 2 Surge Protection with Two Telephone and One Coax Lines , which is also sold here at Amazon .

Took about 3 minutes to install , could n't be easier . I do n't know if it works because I have n't been struck by lightning yet , but Siemens is a good name so I will trust it.From all the units I looked at , I chose this one because it pops in the box and that 's it - no exterior holes , mounting , cable routing , gouging , hacking or swearing . This just popped in and that was it.I bought two , one as a spare.Love it .

Realistically , this is a niche item for most DIYers . I am building a 5 outlet panel for my closet in my spare room . With all my stuff ... Security DVR , router , modem , ecigarette battery chargers , Li-ion tools battery chargers , Lawn Mower battery chargers my spare room was a den of cordless and corded nightmares . So I planned out what i needed and got everything together but the breakers that i needed to run the dedicated line to the outlets . Low and behold I came across this item recommended by Amazon for me . Considering I have hospital grade surge outlets on every one in my home ( not bought here FYI ) i believe Amazon has spies in my packages : - ) . So the surge lunatic that i am ponied the extra 70 $ ( versus 30 $ for two standard beaker ) and placed my order on Amazon . I can tell you a couple of things about this product , It fit in my electrical panel ( GE ) perfectly ( took up two breaker spots , gave me two working breakers , It was east to install . It also has given me piece of mind . Other than those things , until an event triggers the extra protection , I can say that as a dual breaker it is as good as any other breaker I have installed . A lot of electricians swear by these TYPES of whole house protection , so that is as far as I got with if this was a worthwhile investment .

This came quickly and installed fast with the simple included instructions ; provides whole-house surge protection where installed.Warning - NOT for homeowner - requires removal of the main electrical panel cover and if you do n't know what you 're doing , HIRE AN ELECTRICIAN ! !

Note : You will need two 20 Amp circuits next to each other for this product ( or relocate them to be next to each other ) . Or you can buy a 15 amp , or other versions of this product . The two circuits must also not be tied . ( Eg : 220v items such as dryers , ac units furnaces etc . ) .The surge protector/breaker was very easy to install with standard electrical tools . Total install time for two of these ( one per 200A panel ) . Was less than 15 minutes . You should install one of these per subpanel.The device protects from phase to ground through the neutral wire , so you should ensure your neutral is suitably sized ( if it were n't you should have fixed this by now anyway - it 's a major code violation ) - should never be a problem really.Anyway good protector - good results so far , no failures . I do wish it had a buzzer to notify of a failed protection though . I just check it every so often.Shut off main power and follow all code and safety regulations before working with this product . If you do n't know how to install it - ask for help , or find an electrician .

My house has 4 wires from the furnace/AC to the thermostat , and no spares . You may have read that this thermostat will need external power in this case , or a new line run from the thermostat to power the unit . That is not 100 % correct.I had R , W , Y , and G. I connected my G wire to C ( labelled 24Com ) at the thermostat and moved the G wire to the C terminal at the furnace . Then I put a jumper from the Y to G at the furnace . Doing this removes the ability to manually turn the fan on , but it runs properly when heating or cooling . Honeywell has a video on YouTube that describes the process . You may screw it up , void your warranty , and destroy the device . You have been warned.It works fine for me with 4 wires . I 'm using a VeraLite to control the device , but it works as a standalone unit as well . If I change the temperature at the wall , it has changed in Vera before I can make it to the computer.This thermostat is a great value .

Before I started installation I was expecting it to take hours and figured I would have some type of complication . However installation was a complete breeze and took less than 30 minutes total . First of all the instructions were large and I found them very easy to understand and follow . I had my old thermostat removed and my newer and much smarter thermostat installed with no frustration at all . Once installation was complete I was able to link it to my Nexia Bridge in just a few minutes . Once connected to the Nexia Bridge then you can control your thermostat from your iPad , iPhone , iPod touch or Android device . I use my iPad and I really like the app because it 's simple to use and allows you to do so much . All you have to do is register online and download the Nexia Home Intelligence app to your device and login . Then you can view the current temperature inside and outside the house , change to heat or a/c , raise or lower the thermostat , turn the fan on or off or set to auto or energy saving mode . You can create schedules to conserve energy and lower the thermostat while you are asleep or away at work . You can also see a log that will let you see every adjustment that is made to the thermostat . The thermostat also has a built in timer that will flash and remind you when to change your furnace filter . I absolutely love this thermostat except for one thing . You must purchase a subscription in order to use the app for any remotely controlled functions and without those options that it 's pretty much a standard thermostat . You might find the subscription cost a little pricey if you are only using it for this thermostat but it would seem more reasonable if you are using it with other Z-Wave products like electronic door locks , light dimmers , wireless security cameras , motion sensors and window or door sensors . You can create quite an amazing and smart home network but I 'll warn you it can be costly you not only have the purchase price of the equipment but also monthly subscription plan for remote access . Overall I am really impressed my all you can do with this thermostat and would highly recommend it .

After reading other reviews , I purchased this to add to my ADT Pulse . It was very easy to add to the Pulse system and is working great . The reason I gave it 4 stars is because I like to use a daily program to run my HVAC , then modify it as necessary during the day ( either warmer or cooler ) . This thermostat has a scheduling function , but it 's turned off by default . And to turn it on you need to access an installer screen . I did this and now I have a schedule set up . But the assumption is that you will control the thermostat from your Z-wave controller , so the scheduling program is off . It took a while to find this info because the instruction sheet that comes with the thermostat is about installing and basic usage . They 're great directions for what they do , but I had to go through the Trane website to find the user manual.My HVAC system already had a 5-wire hookup , so that aided in making the installation easy . I had to hook up the 5th wire to the power supply , but the included instructions advised where to make the connections on the HVAC fan circuit board . It was a breeze . I 'm not sure how it would have gone without the 5th wire , so I checked to make sure I had it before ordering . I would strongly advise doing the same thing .

I 've lived in my loft for 8 years now . In addition to the cheap thermostat the builder put in , I 've had a Honeywell and a Hunter thermostat . Each of them would take the temp ( heat or cold ) to 1 degree past the setting - example : Summer setting at 77 , thermostat would turn on at 78 and off at 76 . If I wanted it to turn off at 76 I 'd put it at 76 . I have to say , this baby is accurate . It turns off at the temp I set it at - exactly ! I had a problem initially to get power to the condenser outside and put my old one back on because it was 92 outside and their support was closed . Called them today , great tech gave me the exact steps to take , was n't wiring , was in the setup for my heat pump . It works perfectly now and setup with my micasa was a breeze . Now my entire house is automated and accessible on my android via AutHomationHD app , free , speedy and works great .

Got two for my home . Connected to z-wave alarm system . Can now program from phone or computer as well as manually . Much easier to program on computer as it is all graphical . Can also set actions for various sensor conditions . For example the temp set point can be changed based upon arming the alarm system . Very handy . Other features ( learning my preferences ) not yet explored . So far I 'm a happy shopper .

This is a new geenration of the Trane / RCS thermostat.Not only the case is different , also the inside board layout has changed.Apart from that it works just identical to the previous model.I used this to replace an older honywell upstairs ( i have a zoned system ) . Now both zones have their own Z-Wave control .

After reading some of the reviews from others , this thermostat actually works with the ADT Pulse . The enrollment to the ADT system was painless , once connected it will say unsupported thermostat but still work with no issues . Great replacement for the RCS thermostat and also cost less recommended .

Recently started buying DeWalt tools . The best decision I 've made with regard to tools . This drill is light , strong and speed adjustable . It has a three speed transmission - pick speed for the job . There 's a light with 20 second delay . Drilling steel and could not slow it down . Has the 3.0 AH battery that should hold a charge for quite a while . The battery charged in a 30 minutes . I have nothing but good things to say about this drill . I 'm very glad I purchased it.After some time and use goes buy , I will revisit this review with a update.02/20/12Have used drill a number of time since first review . My review needs to add 5 more stars , this drill is great . I know why you see this drill on those home improvement and DIY shows , there 's none better . Drilling concrete and the three speed transmission ca n't be beat . The battery is almost , if not unstoppable . Need a hammer drill buy this one .
Item is very good and has done a good job for us . It does not have he belt clip but that is not a problem at this time .

I 'm not a professional carpenter , but my brother is and when he tells me there 's no better cordless drill than a DeWALT , I place a lot of value in that kind of endorsement . This is the drill he turns to when he 's not using the industrial corded drills on his work sites and it 's been nothing but durable and reliable for him whether he 's drilling holes or screwing wall frames into concrete.I live in a New York City apartment , so I have limited opportunities to push this drill to the limits . The buildings here are old and some of the walls might as well be made of concrete and metal ( actually , some of them probably are ! ) . I wish I 'd had this a few months ago when I was putting up shades in one of the rooms and had to drill through the metal window frame . My roommate 's & lt ; $ 100 Black & Decker just was n't up to the task and what ended up taking hours probably would have taken minutes with this DeWALT , especially with the hammerdrill option . The drill has two rechargeable batteries , an AC charger , a detachable side handle , and a durable plastic case that holds it all . It 's a bit overkill for my current needs , but will serve me very well for years to come ( and there 's no way I 'll be able to go back to cheaper inferior drills ) .Some people have pointed out that , despite the product description , the batteries are actually 18-volt . Another gripe I 've seen is that the batteries take longer to charge than those of competing drills ( my brother 's only gripe is about the batteries , hence 4/5 stars ) . I have n't tested competing drills of this caliber so I ca n't offer a useful opinion on that .

I 've always just borrowed a hammer drill when needed . I 've used the older Dewalt 18v hammer drill enough to know this one is a great update and made me finally break down and buy my own.This thing has so much power and the rpm 's are crazy fast . I do n't know of anything this thing ca n't go through ! On top of that it can still be gentle enough to put a screw into more delicate places.The grip is perfect in my hands and does n't feel too heavy at all . If you have small hands or need less weight I 'd go for the 1.5 battery as it does make it a bit lighter . I do feel it makes it a bit top heavy with the smaller battery but nothing too bad . If you do n't need the hammerdrill function and want a lighter tool you may be better off with the 12v drill honestly . I wanted something that no matter what the job I could pick up one tool and this really does the trick . I was waiting to see if they release a brushless version of this but decided to go ahead and get this because I needed something now and who knows when they will put one out.With this and the brushless impact drill I have a powerful set of tools that will last me for years to come.One last note . I 've read about some wobble issues but I can say mine has hardly any wobble even with long bit . Might be a hit and miss thing to be honest . My only grip is that it did not come with the belt clip out of the box . The standard drill does so I figured this should as well . No biggie but it is the little things that bug me sometimes .

Let 's start out with the fact that I 'm a casual DIY'er . For me , this product is overkill , so I had a professional handyman and a relative who 's an advanced DIY'er give me their impressions of this hammer drill.It packs great torque . There 's plenty of power -- and power to spare , because it comes with a second battery so you can keep one at full charge at all times while you 're working with the other battery.Along with the power and the heavy-duty battery comes some weight . It 's great for most applications , but a pro might feel it 's a little too heavy if he/she has to keep it upright for a long time while working construction , drywall , etc.The keyless chuck is great and very convenient . The hand grip is solid and supportive , and the switch/power trigger is well located for comfortable use.All major functions checked out extremely well : drill , hammerdrill , and driver.Highly recommended !

I bought this to replace a 10 year old Makita that had a lot of use and I thought was a pretty good drill but battery replacement was becoming a hassle and expensive . I am stunned by how much better this DeWalt is . Have all cordless drills gotten this good after 10 years ? I do n't know but WOW ! My first major project using it was to build a shed in which I pretty much fastened together exclusively with 2 to 3 1/2 '' screws . Absolutely no problem , and I only went through 3 battery charges . It 's amusing that it comes with a fast charger when it takes me a week to run the battery down . Amazing.Awesome torque , awesome battery life , awesome chuck , it 's a winner.Update : I was so impressed by this drill that I went out and bought their 20V impact driver and circular saw . Both are very impressive as well . I never thought I 'd say this but I 'm done with corded power hand tools .
It 's built well , works with my other tool batteries . I purchased this toll and the saw in the kit form , and the rest as bear tools to save money .

I have had an older Makita cordless for almost 10 years now . I love that drill . It always had an impressive amount of torque and would last a good long time . But this drill blows it away . The torque on this is unbelievable and the little details are what make this drill great . The LED light is really handy and the ergonomics of the drill are superb.I ca n't recommend this drill enough . It has everything you want in a cordless drill:1 . Plenty of torque2 . Great `` ease of use features '' ( LED , Keyless chuck , good balance , etc ) 3. the battery lats a long time4 . it charges fast5 . the trigger is responsive and allows for good speed controlThe downside to the drill is the case is kinda cheap , although it seems like it would last for a while in the back of a truck , but to really make a drill for this price , they should have given it a slightly better case to handle the rigors of the back of a construction truck ... Otherwise , very impressive new 20v line of tools . New batterys have finally made a nice leap to power tools making them last longer and giving them more power in a light weight package .

I used this to drill in tho my cinderblock basement wall . NO trouble whatsoever . Made what could have been a bi-ahtch of a job to a piece of cake . Plenty of power . I got a great deal too , so it 's best to price shop this by model number , but be careful the 980 is NOT a hammer drill . I made that mistake and had to return that and get this . The 985 is DEFINITELY worth the extra bucks .

Better Ergonomics : This drill feels right in the hand , better balance . By getting rid of the battery stem they gained freedom to design a more ergonomically shaped handle , which I really like . They also lost compatibility with the older XRP pod type batteries , but I much prefer the newer form factor battery . The slide in battery is much more compact and easier to install and remove . This drill is lighter than the 18v XRP drill , mainly due to reduced battery weight . You 'll notice that on the job for sure , and it 's a welcome change . Overall the ergonomics are much improved.Longer Run Time : The 3 Ah battery has 25 % more capacity for longer run time between charges than the 2.4A batteries of the 18V XRP series . And because they are lithium , they do n't have the rapid self discharge of NiCd or NiMh batteries . So you can not use the drill for a month , and it still has charge , but my older batteries would need a refresh . Big improvements , to me.Some Cons : These are really 18v batteries , not 20V -- says so on the box . Dewalt says they call it 20V to avoid confusion with the older 18v XRP line . I find it misleading . I hate to quibble -- these are fine products , big improvements , but I have always trusted Dewalt to be trustworthy . Makes me wonder ... . Another claim is up to 1000 recharges . I 'll believe that when I see it . I typically get 300-500 charges on a lithium battery before it dies , so 1000 is hard to believe , but let 's hope.How you use them can affect battery life . For best battery life , keep the battery cool , not in a hot truck cab if you can avoid it . Lithium batteries degrade faster with heat . Do n't leave them sitting in the charger . And never run it all the way down until the tool stalls . For some reason , Lithium batteries do n't like that . I 'm told there is a shut off in the battery when the battery is close to drained , a safety factor , but why push it ? I 'm not trying to start a debate here , but it 's true that Makita ( and Milwaukee , Bosch , Ryobi , Rigid ) have had this same slide battery style for several years . They are all popular for the reasons mentioned , and I 'm glad Dewalt updated the battery to the slide format , finally . I think competition is a good thing , it keeps them all making improvements and the customer wins.When I checked these out at the Big Box Store , I also looked at the baby brother of this drill , the DCD780 , and I may get it too . It 's much lighter and smaller , and better for those quick jobs like screw driving , assembly/disassembly of things , whenever you just need a light drill without the heavy duty power of this one . Its smaller battery is compatible with the charger and batteries of this one , a convenience.Seems to me there is a lot to like in these new Dewalt `` 20 volt '' tools . The better ergonomics and longer run time are a big win . If you like Dewalt , I think you 'll especially like this new line .

Update 8/27/2012 I found the bit holders for the drill and impact driver and a hard case for my DCD985 drill on ebay all 3 items were less than 30.00 $ Dewalt should have given us a choice to pay an extra 30 $ I 'm just glad they make them and we can buy them.Nice drill but I herad this is just 18 volts not 20 Volts . As well no bit storage Says it 's a option but ca n't find the bit storage anywhere I found the belt clip at dewalt.com . as well whats up with the cheap case [ nylon ] I have an old dewalt 12 volt steel case guess I 'll have to dig it up and see f it will fit . Like I had to do with my 18 volt cordless sawzall with a hard case . when I bought my new dewalt coreded sawsaz with that cheap nylon case ... . Think dewalt should give us a choice of hard and cheap nylon cases , , , I know I 'd pay a bit more for a hard case.As well can anyone here tell what ah means and if 3.0 ah is better than 1.5ah the 1.5 is less expensive and it comes with a hard case . any help would be appreacited . TY Randy FYI The ah stands for amp hours the 3.0 last twice as long running the tool than the 1.5 does ... Please correct me if I 'm wrong .

First , I have to say , `` This is one impressive piece of equipment '' ! Very powerful ! Recently started building a new house and used this to drill our stringer holes through the studs for electrical . It is extremely strong without any bog-down . Some of the holes where through the corners and top plates and it had no problem at all.This drill has lots of power and torque.I was impressed that we were able to use it right out of the box . It comes with two rechargable batteries and a charger . Both batteries were charged and ready to go.I love the hammer-drill feature . It goes through cement like butter , without any hesitation.All-in-all , I am excited about this discovery and look forward to years of putting this drill to work . This has become my new best work buddy. -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- Updated : 10.26.2011This drill is a workhorse and gets used everyday since I received it . There are no signs of loss of torque and the batteries still hold their charge.I 've hung all of my Sheetrock ( about 2300 sq ft ) , Fiberrock ( about 120 sq ft ) , over ninety 3/4 '' drilled anchors into the concrete slab and lots of other holes and screws.As I said before , `` This is one impressive piece of equipment '' ! -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- Updated : 07.29.2013I had to come back an do an update , just to let everyone know that this drill is still running strong . It has far outlasted any previous Bosch or Hitachi drill I 've had and I use it almost everyday and I use this drill hard . Even the batteries have lasted this long without wavering in power loss . It just does n't get any better than this . DeWalt has really outdone themselves with this one.This drill is truly my best work buddy .

My company currently has two of these drills and the guys love them . The battery life is great and the light on the battery that lets you know how much of a charge remains is a big help . Personally I never found a cordless drill with a hammer function that was worth a spit . Then I tried this gun . Let me tell you it can go head to head with my Milwaukee . The 20volt battery gives this drill the guts to chew through some concrete ( small hole under a 5/8 '' ) Honestly last week when I was cleaning out my truck I removed my 1/2 '' milwaukee hammer drill and put it in the shop , No need to cary it any more.Also the chuck in this drill really grabs the bit which is important for a hammer drill . I had one key-less chuck on a hammer drill years ago that would constantly work loose after a few minutes of drilling . Not this one it really grabs the bits . Better-yet it motor locks in place when you start to tighten the chuck , This lets you really bear-down on the chuck.Over all a work horse of drill . Nice job Dewalt !

I think my favorite thing about this drill over the other ones I 've used is that the battery lasts really long on this one . Other things to note is that the light is much brighter and the wider collar is easier to turn to release/tighten the bit . The hammer setting is nice too if you 're drilling through something that has layers with different hardness that makes the drill stop for a second as it goes through them . I do n't even notice them anymore .

Let me preface this by saying , I 'm a girl . I had a different 9.6 volt drill that I had been using for the past few years and it did pretty much everything I needed ( some things easier than others ) until the squirrel decided to move into my dryer vent and I needed to put up a cover on my brick house . Needless to say , my little drill could n't begin to drill into the brick . So , when I saw this , I decided to give it a try.The first thing I noticed were the heavy duty latches on the case and I thought , `` Wow , this looks like a heavy duty 'man drill ' case . '' I was thrilled when I took the drill out to find that it was n't heavy at all and the battery packs , being lithium ion , were much smaller than my current drill 's battery pack . Overall , this drill weighs about the same or a little less than my less powerful drill and is easily light enough for a 5'4 '' girl to use . I read the directions ( which were clear and about as simple as possible ) , put the battery in , and pulled the trigger . HOLY COW ! I quickly sat it down thinking maybe this was too much drill for me ! A few days later , I decided it was time to replace the 2X4 in my fence that had insect damage and to try out my new drill . I was screwing 4 '' screws through a 2x4 into a 4x4 without any kind of pre-drilling and they were going in like the wood was butter . The drill had so much power , but even with all the power , was n't stripping the screws out . Once my fence was finished , I realized I was in love with `` The Man Drill '' as it is now known . There is no way my old drill could have handled those long screws without a battle . My mind immediately went to all the household projects I had done in the past where I struggled with a drill that was n't powerful enough ( hanging mini-blinds , installing child locks into my oak cabinets , etc . ) and thought about how much easier those projects would have been if I had had `` The Man Drill '' then.In the past , I have always had issues with my drill battery being dead . I know I 'm not really supposed to , but I got to the point where I just kept it plugged in all the time which was very hard on the battery . I love that this drill comes with two batteries and a charging station . If I have a big job or if one of the batteries is nearly dead , I can be charging the other one while using what is left in the first battery and not lose work time.So , `` The Man Drill '' is now my new favorite power tool . I will be selling the old drill in my next yard sale . I 'm also looking for new things around the house that require drilling so I can play with it . I highly recommend this drill !

This Drill Excellent from several aspects.Lightweight.Has excellent torque.Provider by two batteries and operates long a time . Was used by the period of April , 2012 but still works with excellent efficiency .

I read a bunch of reviews about this drill prior to purchasing it and I was hesitant to buy having read the comments about it having a wobbly chuck . I did experience the wobble initially , but I either do n't notice it at this point or it 's gone away.Overall , this drill is amazing . It 's stood up to every task an average DIYer could throw at it . The batteries last for a really long time ( do n't have exact numbers ) even when stored for extended periods of time , and they charge quickly . The torque and power have been adequate for my needs and I 've never found myself reaching for something else that was more powerful to get the job done.I have large hands but I did not find this drill to be small in any way - I 'm able to comfortably hold it and it 's well balanced . It 's nice that it 's small because the drill fits well inside my toolbag for those quick trips to family members houses to fix things.The belt clip does n't seem too useful to me because the drill swings around and weighs my pants down ... .the clip is removable though.The LED can be hit or miss . It 's not positioned in the best of places ( since the chuck usually blocks it ) but it 's come in handy a few times .

I think I 've just found my new weapon of choice ! ! Presently I 'm using : # 1 ) `` Pansy '' , a 9.6V Dewalt drill who handles small screws and pre-drilling .She 's sort of wimpy and has atendency to leave the drill bits behind in the wood. # 2 ) `` Big bad Bob '' an 18V Porter-Cable who handles deck screws and forsner bits but weighs a ton andsometimes requires two hands for control ( I 'm 4'11 '' and of the female persuasion ) I think this little beauty can put both of them out to pasture . The chuck is GENIUS once I stopped pinching my fingers between the sleeve and the body of the drill . This tiny thing takes 1/2 bits ? Incredible ! The belt clip is a nice touch and can be reversed if you 're left-handedThe work light is a handy feature and turns on with the trigger , turns off 20 seconds after you release the trigger.The case is very sturdy and has an interlocking lip which should make it dirt and water resistant.The manufacturers description and the other reviewers cover the technical aspects of the drill very well so there is n't much for me to add.Well , alright , just one nit-picky question . If they can develop a tool this nice why ca n't they come up with a decent instruction manual and maybe a storage slot or clip in the lid of the case ? Their answer : `` No one ever reads it anyway . '' Wonder why ? The manual is a chintzy , road mappy thing in three languages . You have to keep folding and flipping back and forth to find what you want . How long before it will be tossed in a corner or under a work bench never to be seen again ?

18 month update : Performing excellently . Batteries hold their charge even after months of shelf-sitting.First , the disclaimers : ( 1 ) My needs for power tools are relatively modest . While I have a house , my do-it-yourself endeavors are not extensive due to shortfalls in my own time , tools and talent ( depending on the project ) . ( 2 ) With my limitations as a handyman acknowledged : I can and do take on those projects in my DIY wheelhouse . Many of these rely on what is unquestionably the first power tool purchase most people will ever make : a drill . ( 3 ) It 's been at least five years since we had a working battery powered drill in the house . Most will be familiar with the reasons why : rapidly depleted batteries , long charging time and limited power when the going gets tough . For these reasons , I had been using a corded drill exclusively for a long time . ( 4 ) The real test of a tool like this comes over time . Two years ago I broke the cord on a Black and Decker drill that I 'd owned since the 70s . While demanding decades of use probably unrealistic , the real test of this drill will come in five to ten years , when I can see if it still works ( and at this price : the answer better be `` yes '' ) .When this drill arrived , I did not have a significant project to test it on . The following is based on a series of tests using different bit sizes , drilling a variety of hardwood , softwood and metal samples , and screwing/unscrewing a variety of screw types in multiple locations.How does this drill get to five stars ? Pros : -Rapid battery charging . Upon arrival , each of the two battery packs had sufficient charge to power the drill for drilling and screwing . While I was not able to fully deplete them , I powered the drill through a series of drilling/screwing tests using each . Time to return to fully charged was about 20m minutes , which I expect to be more than adequate to keep the drill running on the other battery back even in high load situations.-Excellent balance and feel . This drill stands firmly upright on the battery pack . It 's weight is well distributed and its easy to maneuver to get at work that may not be directly in front of you . Start and stopping are as gradual -- or as instantaneous -- as you 'd like when you depress the variable-speed trigger.-Two speed transmission , 15 torque settings and forward/reverse are available to get the right power level and direction of spin to your job. -- The case holds the drill , battery packs and charger unit.-Thoughtful extras : -- The integrated LED light adds the extra illumination you always seem to need ( no matter how well-lit you thought your workplace was ) -- The bitholder at the bottom stores bits parallel to the side of the battery . Having this there keeps them out of your pockets ( and mouth ! ) Cons : I can only offer two minor gripes about this product . They in no way detract from its overall functionality , but you should be aware of them : -the latches on the case are made from extremely thin metal . While the edges are not razor sharp , they are surprisingly sharp , and the resulting feel is someplace between cheap and potentially dangerous ( if you press really really hard ! ) .-the included user guide is not printed in a booklet form , but instead on both sides of single sheet of paper . This guide is roughly the same size as the road maps we used to keep in the glove box in the days before GPS ... and about as annoying to refold . Why DeWalt chose this instead of a booklet is anybody 's guess , but its not convenient for reference and has a PITA factor in refolding.Assuming it stands up the challenge of long-term use in the hands of a not-so-skilled user : buy with confidence . There 's plenty I do n't know about tools , but know enough that going cheap means buying often ...

I received this drill via the Amazon Vine reviewer program , which frankly surprised me as I am not much of a DIYer . Being female and having a husband who 's not into projects , I had to seek out a way to test drive the Dewalt DCD780C2 20V before reviewing it.My Test : Dismantling a 10 year old wooden playset.I had tried to do it before with manual tools , but quickly gave up as it was just too daunting . Next I purchased a wimpyBlack & Decker GCO14SFB 14-Volt Ni-Cad 3/8-Inch Cordless Drill/Driver with Storage Bag and Stud Sensorpackage . I liked the BD product for quick in-house projects , but the battery life was so-so and definitely under-powered for bigger jobs like the playset dismantle.Enter the DEWALT . Obviously up to the task in power with the 20V , it arrived charged and ready to go , with a charger and an extra battery ( also charged when I opened the box ) . For what amounted to probably 40 bolts and screws being removed , this thing powered through without a hic-up and power to spare on the first battery . I was mightily impressed as this is my first professional grade power tool , and I can now see why individuals who do big projects and/or are consistently doing DIY projects , would invest the money in buying this product . Bottom line : It 's great ! While I did n't need it for my project , the LED light is a very cool feature . Ergonomically speaking ... it fits great in my small hands . The case is not super heavy-duty , but it gets the job done . I like that it holds both ( 1.5 Ah lithium-ion ) batteries , the A/C charger ( compatible with the 12V max and 20V , is dual compatible ) and the compact ( 7.5 '' ) drill/driver . NOTE : 3.0 Ah lithium ion batteries will also work with this drill/driver - sold separately.For a woman who lifts heavy weights in the gym 4x 's a week , this tool was still what I would consider to be 'heavy ' for overhead work . I think most users of this tool would not see that 3.5 pounds as a big deal , but not having much to compare it too , it seemed heavy to me after an hour or so of work.The drill comes with a standard 3 year warranty , 1 year free service contract and a 90-day money back guarantee . The 1.5 Ah lithium ion batteries come with a 2 year free service guarantee.The 5-star rating is well deserved for this tool and its packaging . This is a fantastic drill at a fair price . It would be an excellent quality 'go to ' tool for plumbers , installers of various types , remodelers , woodworkers , and other professionals or hardcore hobbyist , DIY'ers .
After owning many cordless drills , so far , this is the best drill I have ever owned . It is light , compact and powerful . I would buy this drill again if this one got stolen !

It 's immediately apparent when you first use this drill that it is way more powerful than the drills a casual user might pick up for common household chores . This can handle big projects , and the battery lasts a very long time . I 'm not expert on these kinds of things - I had to ask a neighbor what to do about getting drill bits for this to use , but that ended up being simple enough . I also really like the light that automatically turns on during use and off when idle . It 's a nice touch that shows how much attention they paid to what users really need.If all you do is put together the occasional shelf from Ikea , you probably do n't need something this strong . But if you 've got larger projects , especially outdoor stuff , where using a drill with a cord can be a hassle , I think this Dewalt drill is a great choice .

I received this for father 's day as an upgrade to my old 18v DeWalt . What a difference ! The size is just right . It feels good and balanced in the hand . I had thought about buying and extra mini screwdriver for little jobs , but this 20v is so light and compact another purchase would be redundant . Though it is smaller than my old DeWalt it does n't lack in power and torque.The LED is a nice addition and helps a bit in those dark spaces .

I purchased this drill/driver based on a LOT of research , reviews , and shopping to find the best value . It arrived ahead of delivery estimate , performs very well , and drives some heavy duty materials . Only have used it twice so far but each time I put it through two full days of continuous use , day one the battery lasted the entire day ! Day two , after a brief charge the battery lasted until I was finished with the drill . Time will tell .

This is a very nice unit . It is not extremely heavy so it makes it very easy to use . Excellent quality . We have purchased a number of these for our company and never had any problems with any of them .

This guy 's a hoss ! Dewalt historically has made top quality products . In fact , you 'll find that most all of my power tools are Dewalt . This Li-Ion battery powered drill is no doubt the leader of the pack . Plenty of power and light weight .

Powers through everything , even when using spade bits , forstner bits , or large diameter hole saws . RPM control is good , even at low speed.The belt clip allows use while up a ladder . That was a big plus.My only gripe is that the LED light is obscured by the chuck . Unless your drill or driver bit is at least 8 '' long , the chuck will cast a shadow right where you need the light . I 'm tempted to tape over the light because it makes the contact point dark by contrast .

Be still my beating heart ! When this drill arrived at my home , we opened the box and just stood in silence for a few minutes.I 've been happily using my Black & Decker Power Driver - with an occasional outing of my corded drill - for decades . I 've also been the family-handyperson for those decades , working with seriously underpowered tools , and severe hand arthritis . Given these limitations , I was delighted to try the Dewalt Compact Drill/Driver.The Dewalt comes in a molded , hinged case , with both batteries charged and ready to use . The case has a small hole for a quick zip-tie lock , or you could pad-lock the handle . The case is well-balanced for carrying , and is fairly compact.The Drill is well-balanced to hold and use ( remember , this is coming from someone with arthritic hands , so I 'm a harsh judge of poorly designed tools ) . An LED light comes on whenever the power is activated . It 's easy to change bits , and easy to use the drill on slow or high speed , forward or reverse - flips with the usual switch , which also locks the drill . My first project was drilling drainage holes in the bottom of five 5-gallon buckets for growing potatoes . My friend used it to complete installation of a door latch in the garage.All of the parts work smoothly , with nicely engineered clicks , and clear yellow/black markings on the drill . It 's easy to see how the battery fits on the base or the charger . Everything is good-sized ; no itty-bitty switches , markings , or dials . There 's a clip on the drill for hanging from your belt , or on a tool wall.It 's my first Dewalt tool , and I 'm impressed . Wo n't be my last . Perfect tool for the advanced handyman , contractor , or a woman who needs a real drill . I 'm retiring my beloved B & D power driver !

+++ THE PROS +++ [ + UTILIZES LI-ION TECH ] : Li-Ion offers more power in a smaller/lighter package , vs. NiCad and NiMH . [ + LED GUIDE LIGHT ] : Positioned above the trigger . Turns on when you pull the trigger and auto-off after 20-seconds of non-use [ + 2-SPEED MOTOR ] : High speed ( up to 2,000rpm ) for drilling , Low/Variable speed ( up to 600rpm ) with clutch for driving [ + LIGHT WEIGHT ] : The 1.5A batteries weigh 12oz each . With battery inserted the total drill weight is 3.5lbs [ + 2 X 1.5A BATTERIES ] : With each 1.5A battery capable of providing several hours of runtime , you 're not actually giving up much runtime at all to have a lighter drill ( vs. having a single 3.0A battery ) . That , in combination with the quick-charger being able to charge a battery faster than it takes to drain one ... You could actually keep working with the drill on-stop , perpetually . [ + DUAL VOLTAGE QUICK CHARGER ] : Charges a battery in 30min and if you happen to also use Dewalts ' 12V MAX line , this charger will charge those batteries as well . [ + INCLUDES HEAVY-DUTY CARRY CASE ] : With the included belt-clip , the drill could just as easily be a part of your tool belt or be in your tool box/chest . But if you like having a place for everything and everything in its ' place , then the included case keeps your 20v kit together nicely and should be strong enough for the job site -- - THE CONS -- - [ - ACTUALLY 18V SYSTEM ] : At full charge and checked with no load , you get the 20V reading . The actual in-use voltage is 18V . But so as to not confuse this new line with their other 18V lines that do n't use Li-Ion , Dewalt calls these the 20V `` MAX '' system . So you 'll need to remove the voltage difference , when doing comparison shopping , to other 18V systems . *** FINAL THOUGHTS ***I 've got big hands ( XL size gloves ) and find this drill to be comfortable to hold , well balanced and even only after a short time of use the lighter weight is appreciated . The included instructions warn that using the variable speed of the drill can shorten the life of the motor , so it 's especially nice having a clutch so you can just run the motor full tilt all the time and have the clutch kick-in at the right amount of tightness/torque you want.This is a new product line , based on the long time success of the 18V line and brought up to current technology and ergonomics . Well recommended .

It was just what I expected , except it came with two batteries , not one ! I think the price was on the high end , but it is an outstanding piece of equipment and something that works well is worth having

Like many guys I 've spent time doing construction . My first cordless drill was the original Makita , which lasted me through a couple of battery replacements . Since I 'd gotten back to a desk and had lost the wrist strength to a use pro grade cordless , I replaced it with aBlack & Decker VPX1212X Li-Ion 14.4-Volt VPX Drill Driver , which is light enough to use and powerful enough to drive screws through 2x4s . For bigger jobs , though its batteries did n't last long enough and took too long to recharge.Enter the DeWALT . With its lithium ion batteries , it 's light enough for me to use for hours . The batteries last for hours , too . I spent all day putting up a fence . The first battery got me through lunch and into the afternoon . I gave out before the second battery did about time to put some fish on the grill . It has plenty of power . It is n't an impact driver drill , which makes is slightly less powerful . On the plus side of that it has an adjustable clutch . When I get tired I rely on that a lot to not overdrive screws . It has two speeds . High is plenty fast enough to run a drill . Low has a variable speed , which is nice on delicate work . The handle is just right for my med-large glove size and can be used by those with smaller hands.The drill has all the little features I 'd expect on a pro model . There 's an LED light , a lanyard clip and a belt clip , as well as a clip to hold a screw bit . One nice touch is that the belt clip and screw bit holder are removable and can be switched for left handed users . It has a 1/2 inch chuck.I have a 25 year old DeWALT belt sander and a Porter Cable ( same company ) orbital sander that are both still going strong and have always considered DeWalt to make rugged and dependable tools . This has a 3 year limited warrante and a 1 year full one . As a home owner I expect this to last , though lithium ion batteries have a definite shelf life limit .

This is an excellent compact drill . It 's lightweight , a little less than 3-1/2 pounds . The ergonomics are excellent , it feels great in your hand . It 's easy to use overhead , or with your arm extended.It has two speeds , 0-600 rpm and 0-2000 rpm . The 2000 max rpm is fast for a cordless drill . 2000 rpm is great for drilling small holes , soft woods , or plastics . The faster the speed you can run , the faster you can drill the hole . ( of course you do n't want to use a higher than recommended rpm for the material or drill bit you 're using ) The drill has a 1/2 '' chuck that runs dead true . I 've seen a couple of reviews that talk about chuck runout , but my drill and the two we have at work run dead true . I take excellent care of my drill , but the two at work see hard usage without any problems.The drill has 15 clutch settings to give you great control when driving screws . It comes with two 1.5 Ah lithium ion batteries that are small , light , yet powerful . The batteries charge in 30 minutes , have excellent runtime and hold their charge well while stored . Even the included hard case is well thought out . It is compact and holds everything securely . The drill also comes with a belt clip and a bit holder . Both are removable and can be assembled on either side of the drill.The drill has an LED light that stays on about 20 seconds after you release the trigger . The placement of the light could be a little better as the light is somewhat blocked at the point of use by the chuck . The Bosch compact cordless drill ( DDS181-02 ) has the light down at the base of the handle and is angled up to a point out in front of the chuck . That method works better . I had originally purchased the Bosch , but took it back and replaced it with this DeWALT . Do n't get me wrong , the Bosch is a very good drill with plenty of power . To me It just did n't have the fit , feel , or build quality of the DeWALT.Additional ( and maybe even useful ) information : This is not the most powerful drill in its class . It may have traded some torque for higher speed . I think that its a good trade off in a compact drill.DeWALT is bringing the assembly of this model drill back to the USA ( North Carolina ) . They will have information on their website . I 've had mine for almost a year so it is n't USA assembled.DeWALT has a new 20 volt max brushless compact drill model DCD790C2 . Be sure to check it out before you close the deal on a new cordless drill.Also , if you 're looking at compact drill drivers you may want to check out the 12 volt offerings from DeWALT , Milwaukee , Bosch , and Makita . They are less powerful , but smaller and lighter .

This is an amazing drill . With the new design grip and the lighter feel , you have total control of this drill . The one problem that I have is the drill box is so compact , you have no room to place drill bits or common & phillip head screw drivers . Instead of having to carry my drill and a case of drill bits , I ended up removing my old Dewalt 18v drill from its carrier and placed the new drill & hardware in the larger case . Not only does everything fit snug but I was able to put a small pouch of drill & screwdriver bits inside.I also noticed that with the older Dewalt drills you could tighten & loosen a bit by just runnig the drill and you would lock the bit in place or remove a bit . I found that when I do this with the new drill , the bit becomes loose after a while . All you need to do is hand tighten the bit in place and it works fine.I had to either replace my 18v batteries or purchase the compact Dewalt DCD780C2 . When I felt this new drill in my hand and the power it puts out , I knew I made the right choice .

I purchased this to replace an older Dewalt portable drill , which is a favorite of mine . Batteries are now expensive and a problem for it , so I decided rather than investing in new batteries , I 'd invest in an all-new drill , especially as li-ion and the brushless motors were highly regarded by reviews pretty much everywhere.I 'll just be straight about this ... . it 's really an excellent drill . I was afraid it would be heavy , it is feather-light . I was n't sure about the battery power , it has plenty of power . And I thought perhaps the size would be awkward , it 's actually smaller than my 12V Dewalt that it replaced.I was drilling out a brass cleat in a deck , and it powered through like it was corded drill ( but to be clear , this does not have the power of a corded drill , but it 's closer than any other portable I 've used ) .If I have one complaint , it 's the chuck . I was using large bits that had the chuck opened up completely , and it struggled to grip onto them . However , this was hard core drilling into concrete and metal with a lot of vibration , but even so , that did not impress me about the drill.As far as people with complaints about the bits not running true , I did n't notice anything particularly bad about this drill . Perhaps my applications are n't sensitive to this flaw . Or maybe Dewalt fixed it . I 'm not sure.I would purchase this again .

This is the drill I needed a month ago when I was taking apart a play set I had built for my son eight years ago ! Instead I purchased a Hitachi DS120DVF3 cordless drill which did n't have enough power for about 1/3 of the screws and I ended up dragging out my 100 ' extension cord and using my electric drill to finish the project.Needless to say this more expensive and more powerful drive works much better than that one . I just ran a side by side test and the DeWalt drill easily out-performed my cheaper Hitachi . The Li-Ion battery lasts much longer as well and the hand grip is actually smaller than the Hitachi which makes it easier for me to hold on to . It does weigh a bit more than the Hitachi -- but I can handle that.I know DeWALT is a quality name ( my ex-husband always insisted on buying DeWalt when possible ) and this one does n't disappoint with the nice extra features like the belt clip , clip to hold a bit , and the built in light ( which was a pleasant surprise ) ! The two speeds and numerous clutch adjustments provides plenty of ways to adjust the power and speed.I also like how compact the case box is -- it easily fits the drill , extra battery , and recharger , but the overall dimensions are small ( 4.5x10x15 ) which means it packs well and does n't take up any extra space -- whether that is on a shelf , or in a larger tool box.Bottom line : This is a nice top-of-the-line drill . I feel like building something . . .

The power and torque of this drill rival any cordless drill I have ever used . There are multiple settings to adjust for torque . The light on the drill has been useful in more than one instance when there would have been insufficient light otherwise . I have used it for simple , around the house jobs such as placing wood screws and drilling pilot holes . This drill does more than I need it to do . It would make a great Father 's Day gift .

I 'm not a person that believes that the tool is the beginning and the end . I felt that given any brand tool one could do the job and do the job well . I still feel that way ; here 's the but . If you want to do it faster and better , than get a name brand tool . I chose DeWalt and I 'm very happy.This is my first DeWalt . In a word `` WOW '' . It is smaller , faster , stronger , lighter and will last longer than any thing I had before it . I purchased it thru e-bay because the price was right and my brand new , not a name brand impact driver just did n't have it . I have used this DeWalt a few times and there is no comparison . I 'll give my no name impact driver away.The tool is well thought out , down to one hand bit changes . There are three LED 's that light the way and stay lit for 20 seconds after trigger release . I do wonder if the handle would survive a drop , it seems on the small side . I 'll just trust that DeWalt knows what it 's doing . After buying this impact driver I purchased four more DeWalt 's and will review each.You can buy what you want ; I would recommend DeWalt - PERIOD .

Have had this unit since the product line launched . It is well built and lightweight . I have . Other dewalt products and like all of them it is robust , has a nice case , and most of my dewalt stuff that is 10 plus years old still runs great . I did not notice any build quality drop off in this unit from the older dewalt stuff , which you sometimes see in other brands these days as they try and maximize profits . The led lights are a nice touch . It is powerful enough for any job around the home . Most importantly if you are a homeowner looking at a unit like this , is that the batteries last over time , even when not used on a constant basis . I completed most . Major projects around my home sometime ago and no the drill is used for the more minor things that pop up every few weeks or longer . The batteries still answer the call with what seems to be the same power and run time as when it was new .

This impact driver comes with two 20 volt lightweight lithium ion batteries , a battery charger and a case . It is small , light weight , powerful and is a perfect fit in the hand . Bits are simply pushed into the chuck and are securely held in place . Removal is accomplished with a slight foward pull of the outer chuck ring . Simplicity personified . It has three LED lights which provide an unencumbered view . Using a standard 1 '' bit makes it easier to work in tight places . This is a suprisingly powerful tool for its size . The batteries are of the slide-in type so insertion and removal in the driver and the charger are easily handled . This is a highly recommended addition to any ones tool collection . I have a number of Dewalt tools and this is one of the best if not the best.Although the tool is a masterful creation the user information is in the dumbest format ever conceived by man ( or woman although , in honesty , I never met a woman that that would do anything that stupid ) . Instead of the convenient sized multi-page user manual that most knowledgeable tool suppliers provide , DeWalt has decided that all information should be provided on a single sheet of paper measuring approximately 1/2 acre . One would need a pair of field glasses to read all the information . By hooking a back hoe to my tractor I was able to lop off the non-English portion and cut the sheet down to about a 1/4 acre . It is inconcievable to me how a company that can create such a fine tool can also win the award for the most idiotic instruction sheet in the history of user instruction provisioning . Maybe they save one or two cents on a $ 220 item . Go figure .
This is an awesome tool . It 's power and compactness are unrivaled . The led lights are a welcome add-on . Do buy !

This is one spectacular hand tool ! I was keen to use it as a drill when I first got my hands on it , but quickly discovered that my old drill bits of various sizes were incompatible with the 1/4-inch chuck . No problem . I came back to Amazon.com and bought the Makita T-01389 62-Piece Impact Drill-Driver Bit Set , which works perfectly with the DeWalt impact driver.What do I like about it ? The torque is phenomenal and drives screws into wood that would otherwise require the drilling of a pilot hole first . The three LEDs are a life-saver when working in dimly lit spots and I especially appreciate the stay-on feature after I release the trigger.What is conspicuously absent ? Some kind of torque setting to prevent over-torquing screws and bolts . In my judgment , that 's what makes this a four-star product instead of earning the full five stars.That said , the DeWalt impact driver is my new most favorite tool .

Having mostly used standard non impact drills most of my life , I was really impressed with the better driving force of one of these , a contractor brought to a job to do for us . The impact drive is so much more forceful a drive ; and a friend of ours Clair Davis , just sears by his DeWALT tools , preferring them over most everything else . I have to agree with him for the most part , now that we have had to use differing tools , side by side.I like the 1.5 Ah model , the 1/4 '' drive is good or all our intended purposes we have encountered around the homestead the past thirty years or so , and the 20-volt does have the drive power , and run time we are happy to have achieved.I can definitely recommend the 1.5 Ah or even th 3.0 Ah our friend has ; for most anything a homeowner will need .

This driver excels as a compact unit with a minimum of fuss . Charge and go . I find this particular unit to be very handy and wonderful to use in tight spaces . So far I 've had good experience with the batteries . The new lithium ion batteries are the way to go . The supplied 1.5 amp hour batteries have been sufficient for my DIY activities , providing plenty of power to get jobs done , and holding charges well between jobs . The trigger activated LED light is great . The charger and kit box are fine.When you buy a cordless tool , you are buying into the battery system and a whole family of tools . The 20v battery , and this entire line for that matter , represent a new generation of cordless tools for Dewalt . They 've been selling the 18v line for a while and it has a big following , especially among contractors . The new 20v tools are not backward compatible with 18v , but I believe Dewalt will be supporting the installed base of 18v tools for a while . The 20v batteries CAN use the 12v Max charger . Do not be confused by the 20v Max marketing . These have the same voltage as the earlier system ( maximum 4 volts per cell , 5 cells per battery , dropping to 3.6 volts when in use ... 18 volts ) , but the electronics are updated and the batteries have higher amp hours ( currently $ 99 for 3 amp hours and $ 69 for 1.5 amp hours ) . The old batteries were nicads ; these new batteries are lithium ion . Dewalt moved the electronics from the battery to the tool , supposedly making the batteries less expensive.I have not had the opportunity to compare this driver to the current crop of lithium ion powered drivers from Dewalt 's competitors ( who include Milwaukee Tools , Makita , Bosch , and Rigid ) . Apologies to those of you looking for a shoot out.If you are not familiar with impact drivers , please read the section below . If you are interested in a more generally useful cordless drill ( i.e. , applicable to a wider number of jobs ) , I strongly recommend the Dewalt DCD 980 or DCD 985 . If you just want a drill for infrequent general purpose household use , get a decent corded 1/2 '' variable speed drill.Here are the basic differences between a drill , impact driver and hammer drill : -A standard drill just rotates.-An impact driver rotates and applies a rotational tapping.-A hammer drill rotates and hammers the drill along the axis of rotation ( i.e. , into the material ) .Impact drivers are at their best in turning screws and nuts , and they are fantastic if you are trying to remove a frozen screw . Imagine nearly stripping a screw and thinking you might need to drill it out , and then using an impact driver that turns it like you 're moving through butter . Impact drivers are not my first choice for drilling of any kind , though the manufacturers are happy to sell you small diameter drill bit sets for impact drivers.Impact drivers place increased stress on the bits and use a hexagonal shank . You should purchase bits that are designed for impact drivers . None are included in this kit . The various manufacturers have their own names for these lines of bits ( e.g. , `` impact ready '' ) but these are not proprietary systems ( though you do need to get a 1/4 '' hex shank for this tool ) . Right now I 'm partial to the Milwaukee Tools shockwave bits , but your mileage will vary . You may want to check out the selection at your local hardware store first before you purchase . Bits are a significant investment . You can also buy adaptors that allow you to use a wider variety of bits ( e.g . round shank ) , but that starts to turn the tool ( or drill bit ) into something it was not designed to be in the first place.Cheers
Relatively light weight , especially considering how much torque it has . It is a tool that I really enjoy using and wonder why I was using a drill with a cord to cinch screw nails .

Once I got over the fact that I spent so much on a 1/4 inch impact I focused on the positives . This is a lightweight , powerful and compact little impact . Works great for around the house and for doing odds and ends . I would not recommend if you are thinking this is going to be a & # 34 ; strong & # 34 ; impact to get off tough bolts . Just does n't have the power . But it works as described and is an impressive entry level type small impact .

I must confess I 've never used an impact driver before and I really did n't know what to expect ... .This tool is lightweight , with a long lasting battery and enough torque to perform every single job you can think of ... To show how strong it is , once I took my car to it 's annual visit to the mechanics ... Just for a routine check-up ... .
