So Dewalt gets big points here for using Li-Ion batteries , as they will take a charge and simply hold it . How long , I do n't know , but from my experience it 's months and months and months ... Included here is a well-balanced , hefty hammer drill ( which functions as a regular drill just fine ) that I used the most , a reciprocating saw , impact driver , and a pistol-grip LED light , all packed in a larger , tough bag . The only questionable item among them is the light - I have n't really felt a need to use it , though I suppose it 's probably a nice light , bright and long-lasting . It just seems like a toss-in to say `` 4 tool kit '' rather than `` 3 tool kit . '' The hammer drill has been put to use many times around the house for various duties - metal , wood , light and heavy - and not once did I doubt its abilities . This is the first cordless drill that has instilled any confidence in me about its ability to get a job done . Most consumer level drills ( read : cheap ) are really pretty weak , but the Dewalt is , of course , not a consumer-level drill.The reciprocating saw may be meant for cutting joists and plywood , but I actually employed it to hack off some offending thick tree branches that I otherwise would have been out there using a hand-saw on . And it worked beautifully - it made fast work of this apparently menial job . It 's probably overkill , but it 's the tool I had and I 'm thrilled I did n't have to wear out my arm instead with the old hand-saw.You get what you pay for . I know many will balk at the price of this set , but having bought and subsequently replaced at least three low-end drills in the past few years , it 's worth it to invest in a better tool up front . Not only will it last longer , it will do the job better . You may not need all of the tools in this set , but you can buy them separately at more reasonable prices ( though I believe the set is cheaper together - if you have a need for all three tools ... and light . )

True to the Dewalt brand name , this is a combo set that provides a sturdy set of tools that should be sufficient for most homeowners for repairs and small projects ( I have used the set to install screen doors , step railings , and patch some water leakage issues on ceiling ) . One can easily sense the sturdiness of the tools when you hold them the very first time , the battery seems to be heavier than another common brand driver/drill set I own , but not to a point it can be bothersome . The batteries recharge very quickly ( 45 min to less than an hour ) and hold charge quite well , ( though that is dependent on your usage ) .The real issue is the pricepoint - one may be able to find cheaper combos from the same brand if you can do without a brand name work light and the bag etc . Someone wanting to build a collection maybe better off assembling a portolio of tools as needs emerge - though the total price for that approach may be higher . It will provide the flexibility of mix-and-match for various brands , however . For the current listed price ( and rarely goes on sale ) , it is likely to be a tad too expensive for the average homeowner - but for someone who needs a tool set for regular use the sturdiness of the tools and the brand name will be an obvious appeal .

I 'm waiting for the replacement set to arrive . I was able to try out the originals with one battery left in kit upon arrival and found the power great for cordless tools . I would recommend they ship these in an unmarked box though . I 've had this problem before with Dewalt tools . Years ago I ordered a set and they came up missing at the terminal and the tracking just dropped out of existence . That yellow and black box is a dead give-away for anyone who wants great tools . This will be my umteenth set of Dewalt cordless tools and these are as good as the ones from the past . Being a former tradesman ( prior to retiring ) I used just about every brand available . And I kept coming back to Dewalt due to the durability and precision . After I retired I bought a set of Black and Decker tools and added to it over time to get a very large collection of their 18 volt tools . Their tools are great but the batteries did n't hold up long , even brand new ones went bad in months . Black & Decker used to make Dewalt tools . Not sure how that worked out after B & D went belly-up and purchased by Stanley Tools a couple of years back . But Dewalt was always a step or two ahead of B & D in battery tek . Hopefully the batteries will perform well with this set . It is a big investment for me at this point in llife but if it lasts it will be money well spent . I like the bag over the hard plastic cases they used to put their tools in because it does n't take as much room . And I wo n't mind replacing the batteries if I can get good use out of them .

I love these . I started a home renovation and felt my 18v line was aging , and I did n't want to lug around cords throughout the house.I am SO GLAD I got the 20v line . The are tight , solid , and powerful . The batteries connect easier and are half as heavy as the 18v line too.I have a Mag77 , and unless I am cutting 4x , I reach for the 20v Dewalt circular 9 times out of 10.I only wish they had 20v nail guns . I have to keep my 18v around because I have their finish and brad nailer .

As a homeowner , I 've long been content with a very nice collection of 18V cordless tools , Ryobi One+ , which I would characterize as being great for most around the house projects , but not of professional quality . These Dewalt tools are in a different league in terms of being heavy duty and well constructed . If you go to Dewalt 's online user forums , one of the phrases that struck me was someone describing the drill as `` maybe too much drill for me . '' By this the writer meant that this is a drill for someone who needs to screw wood screws , and bore holes , and change bits constantly for a full days work and go home bone tired . It is not a drill you would choose if all you were going to do was hang picture frames . The same goes for all the tools , they are not lightweight , but they are well constructed and powerful . Apparently , previous editions of Dewalt 18V tools were heavier still , but I have no experience with Dewalt prior to this set . And , of course , heavy is not a synonym for sturdy ; these tools are sturdy , and that 's the important part.I should point out something I learned from online research , the 20-Volt MAX is a marketing term . These are basically 18V tools , the batteries are only 20V anode to cathode while not under load . It 's one of those industry terms where one company starts calling their 18V tools 20V , and everyone else follows suit so as not to be disadvantaged . I think Dewalt is pretty much up front about this , and I think they regret this industry trend.The drill is the superstar of this pack . It 's a combination hammer drill , drill , and screwdriver , includes a detachable handle , and is what they call thePremiumversion when sold separately . As an owner of a brick house , I appreciate the need for a hammer drill when I need to drill a hole into solid brick or mortar , frustratingly hard without a hammer drill , easy as pie with one ( and the appropriate masonry bit ) . I am in awe at the build quality of the chuck on this drill , it looks like it should be on a high end drill press and not on a battery powered device ; easy to grasp , steel exterior , and bits clamp into immobility with a satisfying series of clicks . The detachable handle comes off with a quick rotation . Operation is convenient with a thumb switch to reverse direction and a multitude of settings : 3 main modes , 3 gear levels and 22 torque levels . With the full battery , the tool is a bit heavy , and it is here homeowners might want to think if they actually need a set of heavy tools for their around the home projects . Not to be confused with thecompact hammer drill.I had some left over 3/4 '' Brazilian cherry flooring which seemed like a good pick due to hardness for a quick race between my old drill and the Dewalt . My old drill worked fine , a 3/4 '' paddle bit went right through , maybe snagging just a bit , but the new drill just zipped through nearly effortlessly with the same bit . Talk about things that make you say `` whoa '' , so I did it a few more times just for fun.The circular saw is , again , heavy duty for a cordless tool . Changing the blade is reasonably convenient , just locate the button to lock the spindle while loosening and tightening the blade . It could be easier , but once in place , the blade is solidly attached . Making straight cuts was easy enough , and the blade zips through pine , but lining up angled cuts takes a bit of guesswork and care . Again , my old circular saw , the Ryobi , went through my scrap Brazilian cherry surprisingly well , but the Dewalt was barely slowed . Of course , this was with a different blade , and in real use I 'd have chosen a blade designed for a smoother , less splintery cut . Still impressive.The reciprocating saw is comfortable with rubberized handholds . Good to have given the vibrational beating one 's hands take with long sessions of reciprocating . Saw blade attach easily enough , although not as quickly as with my Ryobi . I 'm a big fan of using reciprocating saws withMilwaukee green bladesfor yard work involving quick tree pruning of green limbs . Regardless , be sure you purchase some reciprocating saw blades as this set does n't have any . I took it and a green blade out to the backyard and had some fun lopping off 3 inch branches , and nearly laughing at how easy it was . ( I love reciprocating saws . ) And finally , the flashlight is nice . It is an LED , thankfully , and quite bright but not obnoxiously so . The beam is wide for an LED . The huge battery makes it a bit oddly balanced , but it also makes it stand by itself well , and it has a convenient twisting head with a ring to hang it as needed.The tool I miss from this pack is an impact driver , and it might be a better value to buy the somewhatmore expensive 5 piece kit with an impact driveras the driver is quite expensive as a standalone purchase . Still , theseparate impact driverdoes come with another charger and two half size batteries , and a half size battery would be valuable to have for lightweight projects or for leaving attached to the flashlight . The 20-V MAX ecosystem also includes acompact drill driver , apremium drill driver , a rotary drill , and aright angle drill . As far as I can tell , Dewalt is not packaging any of these as tool only , meaning you will have to buy additional batteries/chargers along with the additional tools , at considerable expense . I hope this changes.I wish Dewalt provided a more rigid case than the provided duffle , as it is I will probably buy a different tool bag . Also , the battery is not as easy as my Ryobi to use ; the battery takes more conscience effort getting it in the charger and onto a tool , although it 's easier to remove . And the Ryobi has little touches like a bracket to keep a screwdriver bit on the drill or a bubble level.It 's cool seeing these very tools used on Mythbusters , or on This Old House.I 'm very impressed by this collection . So much so that when I needed a router over the weekend , I grabbed the Dewalt compact router with very little extra thought . So , highly recommended for those with big projects .

Great compact kit . The 20 volt Max Li-ion batteries are a big improvement over the 18 v. You can add the 1.5 Ah battery if you need something a little lighter weight . Highly recommend adding the brushless impact driver to complete the kit.I use this everyday and have no complaints .

I 've used Dewalt kits borrowed by friends over the years , and they 're fantastic . They 're sturdy , last all day , and were great for home use . Now that I have my own set of tools , it 's time to drill and saw . These are typical of the Dewalt tools I 've used over the years . They feel indestructible.The hammer drill was amazing to use . It drove screws in effortlessly . In fact , it made so effortlessly I felt like I needed to find more screws . It rocked . In a way , it 's more of a drill that I 'll ever need . I honestly felt overwhelmed by it.The circular saw is n't meant for people like me who do n't need a heavy set of tools . The blade chewed through 2x4 's . And the blade was easy to install and remove - and it did n't feel like it was going to come out . Again , it 's too much of a saw for casual or light use.Now , the reciprocating saw was by far my favorite . It felt solid in my hands and after use in my parents ' back yard and garage , I did n't feel any numbness or tingling in my hands , which was my major worry . It 's got a great grip and it made cutting effortless.The flashlight was pretty decent . It made a nice worklight . Not too bright , a good wide area . It stood on the ground and did n't move . The bag is the only seemingly `` cheap '' part of the kit . I 'm worried about tools slamming against each other and possibly damaging the blades . It does have interior pockets to keep the charger and batteries separate.Overall , this is way overkill for an apartment dweller , but this is a great set of tools for homeowners . The set has inspired me to take on some home improvement projects . For the price , it 's a great investment . Although I 'd listen to reviewer Glenn Howes ' advice and consider theDEWALT DCK555X 18-Volt XRP 5 Tool Combo Kit - Hammer/Recip/Circ . Saw/Impact/Lightset if you need an impact driver .

Throw away any other cordless tools you have . The Dewalt 20v just made everything else obsolete.The batterys have great life and alot of power . The circ . saw works better than i thought it would . The impact is small , comfortable and hits hard . The drill is a beast and the LED can light up the night sky . My only problem is with the recipicating saw . IT works great till the blade kept falling out . The 12v are nice too .

2014 Update - Originally when DeWalt released this kit , there was only one option , DCK590 , which I reviewed below . After about eight months though , they released the same kit but with a few very minor upgrades . The circular saw now has a magnesium shoe and the reciprocating saw has four position blade attachment . This revised 'Premium ' kit is DCK592L2 and is the one you should buy . Below is my review for the older DCK590L2 kit : Roughly , three to four times a year , I find myself doing small ( and rarely , mid-sized ) home improvement jobs . Whether it is installing new lighting fixtures , adding new cabinets , replacing a hardwood floor etc , etc ... I have need for decent , but not professional grade tools that are solidly built . For the past ten years or so I have used primarily a mix of corded DeWalt and Milwaukee tools and have usually been pleased , but of course like any other Joe , got tired of constantly fooling with keeping the corded tools powered by using an extension cord . So , with a bit of trepidation , I decided to give this latest cordless 20 volt DeWalt set a shot ( and if it worked well , to sell some of my corded stuff ) . This is my first experience with a decent cordless tool set . During the fall of 2011 , I built a treehouse for my son and a roof over part of my backyard deck . The treehouse took about 30 hours over the course of week and a half and the shingled roof and framing/finishing took maybe ~100 hours over the course of four weeks , working in the evenings after teaching . So , these tools got put to their first real test and did just fine . Here is how the cordless kit did : Circular Saw ( DCS393 ) - Both projects used treated lumber and although I would not call the saw a weak point , compared to the other excellent tools in this kit , it was the weaker link . I was able to saw thru 2x4s and 2x8s with ease and the initial framing went fine . I did run into sometimes slight delays with the two included lithium power packs as one would be finishing charging up as the other had run dry . They do charge up very quickly ( my guesstimate is about 40 minutes ) but when you saw thru dozens of cuts , you can deplete one power pack in around thirty minutes , so you have a ten minute delta of waiting time before you can get back to work ( this is not as evident when using regular untreated lumber ) . The answer was simple , I just purchased an additional power pack and that allowed me to work uninterrupted . I also replaced the stock blade with a much nicer blade as soon as I got the kit . The saw worked fine , but if I were a contractor cutting boards all day long , a more powerful corded saw would be my call for speed 's sake . You can definitely notice a difference in speed between a high amp corded professional saw and this cordless one when making many cuts thru a denser material ( like treated lumber ) . As an example , a 2x8 cut might take seven seconds with this saw if you are in a hurry versus maybe four seconds with a more powerful corded saw . So , I give the saw a 7 or 8 out of ten if you are a contractor and a 10 out of ten if you are a Harry Homeowner . Was just fine for me though , as I dont need to make all my cuts in four seconds , LOL.Recip Saw ( DCS381 ) - Didnt need this as much as the circular saw , but found this to work just fine . Wish it had the different mountable blade positions as other saws I have used in the past . Did very well though when used with the more dense treated lumber . Worked fine with just the two power packs ( with no need for the third one ) . No overheat and no unwanted vibration to the arm either . Have since used this this to great effect for cutting down tree limbs . Give this a 9 out of ten.Hammerdrill ( DCD985 ) - The real gem of the kit . Drills , screws or hammerdrills all in one tool . Used it hour after hour , without overheat or unwanted vibration . Beautiful system for setting torque and power . And have since used it for a smaller concrete job and two duct jobs . Worked fine with just the two power packs ( with no need for the third one ) . For a cordless product , you would not know it . It just works and is every bit as powerful as corded tools I have used previously . Easily a 9.5 out of ten for a contractor and a 10 out of 10 for a Harry Homeowner.Driver ( DCF885 ) - Not used as much as the hammerdrill over the last seven months . Seems to be of the same beautiful quality of the hammerdrill . Very powerful for its size . Unsure , if this value would still hold up if I needed it for long term professional use . Very good vibration modulation for its size . For the Harry Homeowner , 10 out of 10 , especially considering its weight.LED Light ( DCL040 ) - Not quite the same frequency or amplitude ( brightness ) as my MagLight in the garage , but hey , its a frigging flashlight . Bright enough to get the job done and bright enough to easily see by in a pitch black room . Worked just fine . Never got to the point where it depleted one power pack so dont know how long it can last . 10 out of 10 for me personally.Overall , after more than two years with the kit and perhaps 500 to 1000 hours total on it , I would give it a 9.5 out of ten . Glad to get rid of the corded tools I used to own and is a nice addition to my garage . Everything is still going strong and doing just fine . Was waiting for DeWalt to release a 20 Volt Max cordless Jigsaw , and they finally did . I purchased it as well and added it to this set . Very happy with these tools and will continue to add posts every six months or note problems if they occur . So far , five star products for the regular homeowner .

I also have a black & decker set with the same tools - the B & D ; tools are fine and are much cheaper , but if you will be using the tools a lot then the Dewalt set will hold up better and give you the better value.The impact driver is the best tool of the set . Unlike a regular drill or screw driver , when it feels resistance it begins to hammer as it turns - allowing you to drive long screws into wood without slipping on the screw head and stripping it . I have used this tool to drive hundreds of 5 inch screws into wooden fence posts - it got hot but just kept on going - doing an excellent job .

I 've owned several cordless kits/tools over the last couple of decades . My needs have changed as I 've grown in projects , and my old cheap black and decker sets have long since been replaced by Dewalts . I 've had the Dewalt 18V kits for several years and I 've been very happy with them . They last through most small jobs with one charge . They are solid , beefy , and have plenty of power , but are also pretty heavy . I nearly converted over to the Li-ion packs , but the price always kept me from it . Then came the 12v max line , I thought they were perfect for nearly every small job and home use . They are light , solid , and have surprising power in a compact size . The charge they hold may not last the entire project , but the packs are so cheap you can buy a couple extra to finish up ( and not break your wallet ) .Well now we have the 20v Max line . To be honest , if I did n't need to buy some new 18v packs , I would n't have even considered getting these . But I did , and I 'm not disappointed . They all have the same solid , beefy Dewalt design , but now they are light and compact as well . They appear to be nearly as small/compact as the 12v max tools . And these tools hold a charge for much longer than their 12v cousins . ( Sorry , I have n't done a comparison test on how long they all last , 12 vs 18 vs 20 ) .The new Impact driver is equal to the 18v version but lighter . Function and size seem nearly the same , but the 20v is slightly smaller and a good bit lighter ( the 12v is smaller and lighter then any of them ) .The hammer drill is the same as the 18v version , but it is lighter as well . Size and function seem to be exactly the same , just lighter . ( no 12v hammer drill ) The circular saw appears to also be the same as the 18v . Performance seems just the same as the 18v version ( good enough for quick cuts in contruction lumber , but I would n't want to have to use it for all day jobs or on pressure treated lumber ) .Charging seems much faster ( about 30min or so , but do n't hold me to it as I did n't discharge the pack fully ) .The light is a new design , with just a rotating head , function is fine , but I really liked the old snake head of the previous 18v version better.The new reciprocating saw is the only tool I felt was not on par with the 18v version . It is a much lighter and slightly smaller design , but it no longer has the pivoting head and adjustable guard , and the blade lock is stiffer . Performance wise , it still works just as well as the 18v . After thinking about it , I realized that I never actually used the pivot function on the old 18v anyway , so I suppose I ca n't complain about the loss of it . But if that is a function you needed for your work , then you will be disappointed . NOTE : I just read the manual and found that this kit has the DCS381 model saw which does n't have the 4 position blade and adjustable guard . Model DCS380 has the 4 position blade . So if you need that feature do n't get this kit . It looks like just the two piece kit Dewalt DCK292L2 and the single saw kit DCS380L1 have the DCS380 model saw with the 4 position blade feature.The bag is the soft bag , which is nice for the lightness , but not nearly as protective . I guess you just have to adapt to it.In summary , I 'd recommend this set if you are new or moving up from the inexpensive ( and usually low quality ) brands . If you 're already heavy into the old 18v stuff , I would n't bother with a switch until you have to replace them . In all fairness , I have not had much experience with other brands kits ( some Milwaulkee , a Bosch , and a Makita ) I 'm sure they are all great sets , but I was already using Dewalt so I stuck with them .

As most men are , I 'm an AVID fan of power tools ! That being said , I 've had ( and still have ) more than my fair share of different tools and brands , and Dewalt is right up there with my favorite brands . Thus when the DCK590L2 Kit became available in Vine , I was all to happy to give it a whirl.Although I received this via Vine , I 'm ABSOLUTELY NOT predisposed to giving a product a 5 star rating and this being a new battery system , I definitely wanted to give it a thorough workout . Which I absolutely did.I currently own a Hitachi 18v NiCad Kit ( Circ saw , drill , flashlight and impact driver ) , an older Dewalt 18v NiCad kit ( hammer drill , circ saw , recip saw and impact driver ) , and my ( previous to this kit , favorite ) a Makita 18v LiIon kit ( drill , impact driver and recip saw ) . Oh and a $ 50 Harbor Freight 18v NiCad kit ( drill , impact driver , circ saw , recip saw and flashlight ) which although was surprisingly decent , is now in the hands of a female who needed power tools . ; ) . The Makita is an AMAZING piece of kit , and although not *quite* as powerful and robust as this 20v Max system , is still one of the best performers in the industry today . So for me to call this kit my new absolute favorite is saying a lot.-The DCD985 20V MAX Hammer Drill : I used this to drill numerous holes in concrete for 1/2 '' x 2-3/4 '' Wedge Anchors and it was AMAZINGLY easy . The drill had enough torque and power to effortlessly drill 15+ holes like it was corded . I then moved on to using it to drill 6 , 1/2 '' holes into a steel unibody frame to mount a Reese hitch on my fathers minivan . Again , plenty of torque and power . Although these 2 jobs were a couple of days apart , I was still on the initial charge . This 3.0ah battery , no joke , seems like it 'll run forever . This thing is quite heavy and beastly , however . So for the smaller jobs , I still see the Makita getting a lot of use.-The DCF885 20V MAX 1/4-inch impact driver : God I love these things . The Impact Driver is , no joke , one of the BEST inventions ever . And this one flat out performs . I drove HUNDREDS of deck screws with this thing and each and every turn felt like I was driving into butter . Again , battery life is amazing and the 3 LED lights around the chuck really help out when driving into light challenged areas . The DCF885 really blew away the other Impact Drivers in my stable ( including it 's 18v brother ) , which again is saying a LOT.-The DCS381 20V MAX reciprocating saw was used to do everything from demo work ( wood/metal studs , drywall , etc ) to rather large tree limbs and again really impressed me . Definitely the best of the 3 that I currently own . Battery life was amazing as well . Although , I would definitely NOT reccomend using a 1.5ah battery on either of the saws.-The DCS393 20V MAX circular saw was used to cut SEVERAL pieces of timber for a deck that was being built and was absolutely up to the task . Great power , with great battery life . With as much wood as we were cutting , I figured I 'd have to use a corded saw , but both batteries ( one swapped while the other charged ) managed to make it through the whole build . Although for oddly enough , the blade that was included in the kit was rather dull and had to be replaced almost immediately.-The DCL040 20V MAX LED work light is actually QUITE bright . Easy on par with any of the mid-high end 1 watt LED flashlights currently available.-The charger is a high speed charger , takes about 30 minutes to charge and can be used to charge the 12 volt MAX batterys as well as 20v . A nice touch.All-In-All , I continue to be highly impressed with this setup . Although pricey , you definitely get your moneys worth . Black & Decker continues to churn out top quality , industrial grade tools with their Dewalt line .

I purchased the 18 volt XRP in 2001 and then when that combo unit rans its course , I bought this Lithium Ion combo . It does n't disappoint . I built a 14 ' x 10 ' shed , with 1 charge on the battery . With my XRP 's , it would 've taken about 12-15 charges . Excellent product .
I ordered this as a Christmas gift for my husband along with all the other items to complete his Dewalt set . They are high quality tools . He was the envy of his buddies .
I love this item specifically because I no longer have to haul out 600 ' of electrical cord to use it on my property . Hooray no more long cords.Every tool is top quality

If you are used to purchasing cheap stuff from the local hardware store , then a $ 580 kit is going to scare you - and rightfully so . This is a lot of money for a set of power tools . That said , if you actually do more than just hang a couple of shelves , then this kit is obviously not going to let you down.Lets start with the basics : The box : the box this kit comes in is a piece of crap . Upon arrival , the inside soft bag was already poking through three of the corners . It is taped on the tops only , so the corners will most likely rip in transit . That said , all the tools are quite well packaged inside the soft-bag , and some of the parts even come in a bubble envelope , so you do n't run much risk of damage.In the kit , you 'll find the charger , two battery packs , the drill , impact driver , circular saw , reciprocating saw and an LED light . It also includes a basic saw blade for the circular saw , but no bits and no blades for the reciprocating saw , which is a bit of a shame.The drill is simply incredible - this thing weighs a ton , yet is comfortable and extremely powerful . I took it for a spin on several materials , including the concrete floor of my garage , and it had absolutely no problems with what I threw at it.The impact wrench is a tough one -- it 'll help get screws out , but do n't expect to use it to loosen the lug nuts of your car . The LED light is relatively bright , but I get more lumens from a $ 20 Costco LED flashlight . Both saws are what you 'd expect from a kit like this ; powerful . Speed control on the reciprocating saw is a bit lagging , and its lowest speed can be a bit too slow to get things started.The charger has one minor issue that annoyed me -- its LED is RED only . It communicates with you with flashes , so when it is full , it stays fully red . Call me a whiner , but I prefer a charger that shows green , just like every other charger on the market ... Other than this , the 20V `` MAX '' is of course mostly marketing , as the cells themselves probably only produce 18V ( hence the `` MAX '' part -- they will show 20V without load ) . Still , this is one killer power tool set , and if you do some `` real '' work around the house , this kit will NOT let you down .

I am thrilled with this reciprocating saw . I 'm a big DeWalt fan , and the performance of this saw certainly lives up to the DeWalt reputation . It is very solidly-built , nicely balanced , and the grips make it easy to hold on to even if it bucks . I 'm especially fond of the 4 way blade grip ( makes flush cuts a snap ) and that you do n't need a tool to change blades.I was concerned about power since I 'm used to using my 20+ year old corded Milwaukee Sawzall . I 've switched to cordless tools for pretty much everything else , but the cordless reciprocating saws I tried in the past just did n't match the power of my trusty corded Milwaukee.Well , the corded Milwaukee is going to be spending time on the shelf . I 'm pleased to report that the 20v lithium battery provides more than enough power . Zips through lumber with embedded nails like a hot knife through butter . Same with metal stock - as long as the blade is sharp and up to the task , the saw has n't let me down one bit.The run time varies by what you 're doing but I 'm averaging about 30 min per charge . You 'll want to have at least one more battery at the ready since recharge time is about 40 min . That 's my only complaint - the kit should have included 2 batteries instead of just one . It also would have been great if these 20v batteries could be used with the 18v NiCad tools , but I can understand how that would be difficult or impossible to engineer.The case is plastic but quite sturdy , in usual DeWalt fashion . I do miss the days of metal cases ( my Milwaukee has a metal case , but I think they switched to plastic as well in recent years ) but plastic has its advantages as well.Easy to handle , lots of power , decent run time , and solid construction . Ca n't ask for more than that in any tool . Highly recommend .

I also have the 18 volt Black and Decker and Ryobi reciprocating saws . These blows them out of the water . Im remodeling a 112 year old house with real 2x4 's and they are hard old wood . This saw eats right through them with a good blade and the battery life is over twice as long as the other two were when they were brand new . This new lithium 20v line is the way to go if your gon na use your tools often and want the batteries to remain in good condition

Got this to help put up a LOT of fence , and am really impressed with the power and battery life . This replaces Milwaukee equipment , also really good but completely disappointed with the batteries . Dewalt has a very good reputation , now I know why .
It 's built well , works with my other tool batteries . I purchased this toll and the drill in the kit form , and the rest as bear tools to save money .

Best Reciprocating saw I 've owned yet . This saw has the guts to chew through some wood and metal . I 've had other saws with quick release blades , most of them broke or jam after a while . This one is ease to use and works great . We 've put them through some heavy use and can not come up with a complaint , which for my guys is says a lot . Dewalt is doing something right with this 20volt line of tools .

I love this thing . It 's sturdy , produces lots of light , it 's LED and lasts a long time on the battery . However , it 's easy to over-pay for this . The price on this item fluctuates a bit . from like $ 30-50 . On average i noticed it 's about $ 39.99 with Prime . Would n't pay more for it . I love the fact that it fits my 20V batteries . We lost power a while back and I got to use this flashlight for a while before the power came back on . Love it ! A must have in any toolbox that has 20V Dewalt tools in it .

This flash light provides a bright white spot light . It is not a flood light as the beam is more consintrated . Design is nice . Construction is mostly plastic but appears to be pretty durable . I upgraded from my old Dewalt 14.4 volt to the new 20 volt max and this flash light is much better in design and light output .
This light is good , but compared to the snake light on the 18v system , it could have a few improvements made .

The trigger on it seems a little finicky but the light is otherwise great ! It would be nice if it had a two power switch that was better built for longer life low power and brighter for when you need it .

When I got my drill/impact set for the 20v line , after falling in love with their quality and battery life I decided to get the reciprocating saw and flash light as well as a set of the 1.5ah batteries . This light is very bright , works great with the smaller 1.5ah battery and no need to worry about a bulb burning out like I always seemed to do with my old 18 v black and decker and ryobi sets

This is a nice light that is really functional , bright , and light . Gives off a nice white light and you can carry it anywhere . It is smaller than I thought , but that is fine too . It would have been nice to have other hanging or clipping options as you either have to stand it up or hang from it clip , not the best options when you need to shine it in a specific area but do not have the hands to do it or a friend to help . Otherwise , a great lamp .

I 've bought this flashlight and was expecting it to be like most led flashlights ... .Turns out it is a fantastic flashlight ... It 's way stronger than my previews favorite 3 A batteries flashlights ... I really thought that led flashlights would be worse , like rayovacs and other low-end brands ... .I was simply amazed with this product . Once again it carries the DeWalt well known brand and as all the dewalt products I have it works perfect ... ..It 's really bright . It 's flash goes further than 30 meters ... Really a great work light and also a bright flashlight for regular use ... .
Nice bright light will fit in well with my other tools ! ! ! This is going to come in handy ! ! ! Thanks
Works well and is bright.I use 4.0 Ah batteries and they last forever.I can still use battery for power tool even if light has been on a long time .
This light is everything I expected and more . It 's very bright , battery lasts a long time because of the LED bulb . You can easily hang it with the loop on top .

Some people complain about the focused beam , but after receiving mine , i found their points of view to be slightly exaggerated . This little light is amazing . I am using it far more than i thought I would as I find more and more reasons for keeping it handy . HIGHLY RECOMMEND.Also , at less than $ 40 on Amazon.com , this is a much better buy than anywhere else . I do n't know who is making money here ... I suppose Amazon.com is also an authorized distributor of DeWalt products . If that be the case , than the big box stores and other local hardware stores do n't stand a chance at competing ; but hey whatever works . Innovation drives future successes .
This thing is BRIGHT ! It 's a perfect little addition to my new 20v Max kit . The tilting head is nice feature .

This flashlight is an excellent worklight and a must have for those who own any other dewalt 20v max tools or batteries . This flashlight does NOT come with any battery.The light has a single LED with a reflector . The resulting light has a very bright hot spot in the middle with a surrounding circle of light . That said , if you need a flashlight that provides a very wide beam of bright , even light , look elsewhere , or make a light diffuser to go over this flashlight head.Construction is solid.. it has the feel of a drill with the ruberrized grip . Screwholes on either side of the base for installing a drill bit clip and/or a belt clip . However , no clips are included.The flashlight head pivots up and down . I would approximate the range is from -5 degrees ( 5 degrees below horizontal ) to 110 degrees ( 10 degrees past vertical ) . Clicks in the hinge allow you to click the head into a desired angle.A hook at the top allows you to hang the flashlight . When not needed , the hook snaps into a retracted position.The flashlight was smaller than i expected , with a thinner handle than dewalt drills . Compact , light , rugged , bright , buy it !
This is the perfect compliment to your Dewalt 20v drill kit . Good quality and it works fine . Nice and bright with a good switch and the head angles .

The LED outpu , 110 lumens beam shines very clear and very brightand shines a long distance , approximately 200 ft plus.The beam is actually clear ~ how very nice to find a light that is1 . NOT yellow-sh like the old flashlights2 . NOT blue-sh like many LED flashlights3 . Does n't have the dark center like 'mag ' lights do.Both DeWalt batteries ~ the 20 volt 1.5 Ah and 20 volt 3.0 Ah Li-ioncan be used with this light-weight flashlight.It 's head is pivoted to turn down some or straight up.It has a very rugged metal hook for hanging , that also locks down out of the way.And of course it sits firmly , flat on the battery.This light is all around rugged ! I bought the light only , it was n't in a kit , about two months ago at Lowe 's for $ 50.00 plus tax , and have used it nearly every day , several times a day ~ since.Initially I fully charged a 20 volt 1.5 Ah DeWalt batteryand the light is still bright and shows no signs of needing charged yet.Because of the price , it 's best if you can get the light included in a kitor already have other DeWalt cordless tools.It 's a wonderful light , but it would be ridiculously expensiveif you did n't already have a DeWalt charger and some Li-ion batteries.I initially thought this light was very expensive and almost did n't buy itsince the light alone cost $ 50.00.But since I already have the batteries and a charger , I thought I 'd try it.And now that I see what an all around great light it is ~even for how expensive it is ~I absolutely love this flashlight and would n't want to be with-out it .

I purchased this as an afterthought . It actually works well , It sets on the battery like a stand , and the beam is narrow enough I can position it so I can see what I 'm doing without blinding myself . The three amp battery is a bit of overkill for it , but then again it 'll go all day on one charge . It 's also a nice backup when the power goes out . Just note it does not come with a battery . If you have other 20 V max tools you can use their batteries , or you can purchase one separately . I would recommend you buy the 3ah battery far it , since it 's heavier and makes a better stand , the 1.5 battery is a little to lite , it 's to easy to knock over .

I got this light as part of a 20 volt MAX kit I got recently and am pleasantly surprised . Most of the lights included with toolkits are throwaway afterthoughts and are barely useful . The DCL040 changes that . This guy is rugged , easily positionable and QUITE bright . Actually it 's brightness is what really sets this apart . I 'm kind of a flashlight junkie and the DCL040 really gives some of my flashlights costing twice as much a run for their money . The secret is the CREE manufactured 1 watt LED . CREE LED 's are pretty much cream-of-the crop and give off an extremely brilliant white light , which when coupled with a good reflector design , blasts your working area with a blanket of illumination . Which brings me to my next point . Runtime . LED 's are notorious battery savers and this light is no different . Specs rate this as being able to last up to 11 hours with a 3.0 Ah and my own tests confirm this . I was able to get 11hours and 6 minutes of run time before the unit shut off . Which is awesome compared to the incandescent light that came with my Makita Lithium Ion kit , which only managed 4 hours on a 3 ah battery.As I stated earlier , the DCL040 is easily adjustable and positionable . The head can be pivoted 120 degrees and attached to the back is a metal clip that allows the light to be hung for hands-free illumination . But here 's where I ran into the only major issue . The pivoting head . Although it is detented and clicks into place , it 's not tight enough , so the head is easily moved if bumped . I mean , it 's not loose enough to flail all around at that slightest touch , but it is quite easy to move . Not a deal breaker , but worth mentioning.All-in-all , I am quite impressed with this work light and can definitely reccomend it to someone looking for a bright , somewhat compact light source that will stand up to the day-to-day rigors of the job site .

Great tool . I am an experienced DIYer and I have one of these lights in my plumbing box , in my electrical box , and in my general tool box . Thinking about putting one in my cars too . There slightly overpriced , but considering that you 'll probably never have to buy a replacement battery , not too bad .
Bright , sturdy , and lasts forever on the large capacity batteries . It 's also surprisingly adaptable at getting the light where I need it working on cars .

Really pleased with this purchase ... feels comfortable and manageable in the hand , especially when using a 1.5A battery over the larger 3A 20V . I like that there is a flip up loop for hanging in a hands-free situation . Very bright with a focused center and broad outer beam . Overall , definitely the best work light I 've used .

I purchased this flashlight as part of a Dewalt / Amazon end of the year promo.I would not have paid full price for the flashlight due to a limited tool budget.That being said , this is a great flashlight and I 'm glad I bought it.It is bright , you can hang it , or just set it on its base ( battery ) and angle it where you want it.If you have extra 20v Max batteries and want a great LED light this fits the bill .

Keep in mind that when you are finished , you have $ 100+ flashlight . You need the light AND a battery And a charger sold separately . I have the new DeWalt tools with the brushless motors that use these new batteries , which are 4 amp . These tools generally come with two of these batteries . I also bought two extra . So , it is an expensive light , but it is bright . There are cautions about looking directly into the LED ( Light Emiting Diode ) . Believe it and do not look directly into the light - you risk retina damage . The head tilts ( a little too easily for me ) and there is a hanger . The light is not heavy and the over-molded grip makes it comfortable to use . It has a three year warranty as do the batteries . Keep in mind , that if you buy the light and battery , you will need a charger . This is not a problem for me as I have the other tools that use these batteries and they all come with chargers . Kind of a long way of recommending this light is only if you have the new DeWalt tools that use this battery . If you do , the light is an excellent value . If you do n't , well read my first sentence again and then decide .

I have previously reviewed the Dewalt 20v combo kit with hammerdrill and impact driver , adn decided to purchase this wonderful LED light . This really was a great addition and works wonderfully for my purposes . It throws outa brilliant white light that does not bother my eyes . I will say that it is pricey and I probably would n't have paid more for it . I paid $ 40 for it a week ago and now the price is up to $ 46 , and more than likely I would n't spend much more on it than that . Do n't get me wrong it is a great light but you can buy a bevy of cheap LED lights and some more brighter than this one . I justfied my purchase by wanting a light that works with my 20v batteries , of which I have 4 compact.As a whole , I love the 20v line and am excited for it 's future . I am also invested into Milwaukee 's m12 line and would like to see DeWalt take an idea from some of Milwaukee 's innovative tools . I am planning on getting some 4.0 ah batteries , definitely the jig saw , circ saw , and sawzall , and hopefully the 1/2 '' impact wrench with 300 ft/lbs of torque . Thanks for reading , Ray .
Item is very useful . I especially like the fact the you can set it down and adjust the light to where it is needed .

This is a great light but I had to return one , the first light I received would start blinking after about 20 min of use . I scheduled a return though amazon and they promptly shipped me a replacement . Because of the failure of the first light I cant give it a full 5 stars . The second light has been flawless but it does run quite hot . The trigger area warms noticeably after about 10-15 min of use . I have used this light for home projects and have taken it along on a few camping trips , I have n't been able to burn through a full 2.0AH battery even with hours of endless use . In comparison to my surefire lights I would say the stated 110 lumen output specification is pretty accurate .

I have a pile of DeWalt 20V Max batteries , so I bought this flashlight to try and get more use out of the batteries.The flashlight is very handy since it 's always sitting right next to my toolbox , it 's design makes it easy to grab , hold , and use , and I know I will always have a battery handy . The fact that it stands upright on the battery is a big plus.As others have noted , the brightness and beam are the two weaknesses for this flashlight . It is simply too bright for most situations where you are holding the flashlight close to your work . The reflected light is blinding . The first improvement DeWalt could make would be to provide more than one brightness level . A low and high , or low / medium / high would be a huge improvement.Second , the very tight beam is a problem in many workshop situations . If they made the beam adjustable , like the old school Mag Lights , it would be a fantastic feature . The trend with LED flashlights to make a laser-like tight beam is not very helpful for many situations . Sometimes a broad beam is much more valuable.I 'd gladly pay more money for the flashlight if it had those two features.Other than those two weaknesses , it 's a very useful flashlight .

One of the first Dewalt 20v tools I have purchased and it is a world of improvement over the 14.4v light it replaced.This light and the Dewalt 20v Brushless Driver make a potent go anywhere fix anything combo .
This thing is extremely bright and gives long battery life . I am thankful the days of the incandescent lamp are gone !

Love this light and how bright it is.It is multi-functional and the adjustment head goes vertical about 70 degrees up and down.Sadly , it does not focus or have any horizontal movement which is the only drawback .

I got this light as part of a DeWalt 20-Volt Max tool kit . I figured it was just filler to make me think I was getting a better deal , but it turned out to be a very nice light . It 's very bright . Not quite as bright as my 950 lumen LED spotlight , but the sharply focused beam is plenty bright to use for nearly anything around the house , finding stuff in the yard at night , or working under your car . The color of the light is a very neutral white , not the bluish tinted white that you might expect from an LED light . The weight of the battery makes the flashlight very stable , and there 's a chrome hanging loop if you happen to have a hook , nail , drawer knob , or anything similar available.I was somewhat disappointed by the lack of a frosted snap-on floodlight lens to help disperse the light , but I found that I could get a floodlight effect by either shining the light at something nearby ( 2x4 , drywall , white cardboard box , etc ) . Better yet , I was able to get a long-lasting and very effective MacGyver area light by attaching a paper coffee filter to the front of the light with a rubber band . Just form the filter into a rounded ball shape ( think Pac-Man ghost here ) and attach with the rubber band . Much brighter than a fluorescent work light , and lasts for many hours per charge.The base has holes for an optional DeWalt belt clip , and I recommend adding one for carrying the light around . It 's too big to fit into a pocket ( not counting that giant pocket on the front of bib overalls ) , but it 's easy to hang off of a belt with the clip attached .
DEWALT DCL040 20-Volt MAX LED FlashlightGreat deal , I 'm not expiriencing the problems others are having , I use it at work all the time , I work in construction , so far so good .
Did not buy this , got 18v light to match my other De Walt 18v batteries . It has a few more features then my 18v light , but I wanted to stay with the same 18v battery system that I already had .

I finally bought this rotary hammer after constantly pulling out my corded hammer drill for small quick jobs ... I wanted something a bit more convienient . I did n't expect much more than the ability to drill out a couple of holes that were only a inch or two deep ... However , this unit has exceeded my expectations ... . It 's got much more power and performance than I had expected ... I 've drilled holes 6 '' deep without a problem , chipped out tile , and even broke out small pieces of concrete ... It 's become my go-to hammer for all my light to medium work ... Its lightweight and the anti-vibration works perfectly ... I recently used it to to chip out stucco for removing 9 windows and really loved its performance and ease of use - all on one battery ... . Very happy with this Dewalt Rotary Hammer ...
I upgraded from 18v to 20v and gave my old 18v stuff to my son . He is happy and I am happy , how can you beat that .

Got this unit and started drilling 1/4 & # 34 ; holes in block wall for furring strips the very next day . I have a 1 & # 34 ; corded and wanted this ( I HATE CORDS ) to do the every day stuff . Good chipping & # 34 ; just to knock down burrs and sloppy mortar & # 34 ; and the SDS sure beats a regular 18v hammer drill . Drills faster , bits last a long time and I am not tripping on cords . Pretty good run time on the batteries too..
i love this drill . it is light but packs a lot of power . since i got it i have used it many times and had no problems . it is very light and small in size . i would highly recommend it .

I received this tool around the first week of Sept 2011 . I already have a corded hammer drill , and I install commercial doors , windows and frames . When I am on a long-term install , I will be using a corded SDS drill , but I also do service , and small jobs . Too many times to count , I have needed a 1/4 inch hole and a plastic anchor to hold a frame in place , or a threshold , and only need 4 holes , and as you all are very familiar , a drill with a hammering feature ( non SDS ) hardly EVER works on concrete , and if it does , you just burned up at least one bit on one hole . The day I received this kit , I opened the box and put the batteries on an extended charge , first . While they were charging , I went a got a 1/4 inch SDS bit , and a small SDS chisel , and a granite rock . I 've drilled granite for frames , and it is hard to drill , and is hard to chip . For 15 minutes , I drilled holes and chipped to my hearts content . The power is unexpected and in trying to kill the battery , I did not . The MAIN reason I bought this is for the CHIPPING FEATURE . You ca n't find another manufacturer in the 18 volt class with the chipping feature ( that means hammering without turning . Many many times I have needed to chip away just a bit of rock hindering the installation of an aluminum frame or threshold and have to break-out the cord . I prefer not to use cords unless absolutely necessary . Two main reasons : 1 ) Someone is going to pinch your cord ; 2 ) Someone is going to get tangled in the cord ( probably you . ) This unit has no problem drilling holes . Holes it was designed to be drilling ... I have drilled a 1 inch hole through 4 inches of concrete , and it works great , but the is NOT what it was designed for . Really it is for drilling anchor holes up to 5/8 inch all day , and chipping away anomalies such as rock , concrete and pesky screws . It is VERY compact and agile enough to drill holes in concrete while you are 10 feet up a ladder installing a window frame , without worrying about someone yanking you off the ladder with a tangled cord . Also , I have been getting RAVE comments on it . It is the talk of the company , and I plan on using the hell out of it . I will update in one year : Sept 2012.Cons : NO BELT HOOK ! ! ! and no BARE TOOLS offered . I do n't need 88 batteries for 5 tools , and I DO N'T use cases . I USE tools that 's why they make the Husky rolling bag .

I have n't had the chance to do a direct comparison yet , but this rotary hammer looks like it will be able to do what I have been doing with a somewhat larger heavy duty corded rotary hammer . And this is much lighter and not corded . The jury is still out on how well it holds up over time and how many unique uses I can have for it .

DEWALT does ; that 's who . The best battery ever . Charges fast and lasts a long time . The price is high , so look around on line , you can find it much cheaper . People buy the tool and sell the extra battery . Buy the tool with the 1.5 Ah battery and purchase a 3.0 Ah battery and turn your tool into a heavy duty model .

After my old B & D drill kept running out of power , decided to purchase a new drill set . Opted for the DeWalt 20V hammer drill and impact driver combo with the 3.0Ah batteries . The combo came with 2 batteries , but the special at the time gave me a third battery FREE ! ! Talk about a great deal ! Now I 've got as much juice as I can use .

It 's a DeWalt , need I say more ? As expected , build quality is flawless , ergonomics is great , weight is light and longevity is twice that of the smaller batteries . The new series of Lithium Ion tools is fantastic .

I 've got a pair of these batteries with a hammer drill / impact driver I bought from DeWalt . I really loved these batteries . Here 's my opinion : The material : The materials used on these batteries is really strong plastic . They offer some scratch resistance even if its not the main requirement for the product . They are extremely well-made , all the parts fit perfectly against each other . The release button is really strong , allowing for many connect and remove the batteries without a problem . Their size and weight help give the tool a really good balance . A 5 star rating.The battery life : These babies last longer than I would expect from cordless power tools batteries . I can use the impact driver on a daily basis without having to recharge them during a month period . They provide all the power needed to perform the toughest tasks without even complaining . I 've been using them to manufacture power supplies and for each power supply I have to fasten at least 36 hex M8 screws ... I can assemble at least 3 power supplies a day for the whole month and the batteries are still good to go . A5 star rating without a doubt.Overall : These batteries are really tough . They last for a long time , and they take only about 1 hour to fully recharge . I 'd surely give them a 5 star overall rating . The only bad thing about them is the weight , but nothing is perfect . So much power and life really comes with a price.I would definitely recommend these for cordless power tools .
I bough this to have as a spare for the new 20V drills that I had just purchased , it works as good as the OEM batteries .

Yes , it costs more , yes it lasts a LOT longer , yes it saves you time and yes it has a lot of power . This is my first experience with Lithium in more expensive tools and I 'm sold . Used it outdoors a LOT , saves me a lot of time going back and forth to the charger ... oh , and it charges really fast too .

Received 2 of these in the DCK590L2 20-Volt MAX Li-Ion 5-Tool Combo Kit I got and am highly impressed . So impressed that I bought 3 more . This single and a dual pack . Although technically this is really an 18 volt battery , it 's performance is much better than the 18 volt ni-cad batteries in my old Dewalt tools . Not only is runtime enhanced , it 's also much lighter and I love the new slide attachment vs the older clip attachments . It holds much better.I 've used this battery on pretty much every tool in the kit and am continually impressed . For instance , when in use on the Impact Driver , I was able to drive 100+ screws into hard wood before needing a charge . Using the drill , I was able to drill several holes for 1/2 '' x 2-3/4 '' Wedge Anchors , then drill 6 holes in a steel car frame and still had battery left over . The saws , while harder on the battery , were still able to be used to cut several pieces of timber for a outside deck.Dewalt definitely has a winner with the new 20 Volt Max line . I just really do n't like the trend all tool manufacturers are taking with the `` Max '' ratings . Reminds me too much of car audio . But this does n't really matter as long as the tools/batteries perform and these definitely do.I will say , however , these are quite pricey if bought by themselves . But DeWalt is n't alone with it 's battery pricing . Most of the `` contractor-grade '' tool makers tend to get a bit crazy with battery pricing .
lightweight great battery and slim and easy to use ... these slide in instead of grab and click ... better feature and charge is long lasting

For several days I traveled in and out of a building where rooms where being framed out of one large room . Every day I felt a little sorry for those guys when I saw their old worn out cordless saws and drills struggle . Eventually I threw the tool bag in the trunk and let them use my brand spanking new set of 20v tools . When I came by to pick them up at the end of the day the project was complete and NCOIC reciprocated by giving me free pickings to all of their scraps plus excess lumber purchased for the job.Since then I 've gotten a fair amount of use out of them as well as I build this and that with my newly acquired supply of free lumber.Even the old man who built everything from cabinets to complete room additions with hand tools growing up , when I mentioned my new tool set said , `` are they lithium ion batteries ? ... man those are nice . ''

It was free , what else can I say ! . it is cheaper than the older 18v Li-Ion batteries but last longer ? makes you go hhmmmmmmmmmmmmmm ! Are they pushing cheap prices just launch these new products ! Maybe , go ahead and egt'em while you can !
last longer and stronger than 18v . Especially useful in circular saw performance , wet pressure treated woods now can be cut

The Dewalt DCB200 20 volt battery perovides extended time with use with my portable drills and impact wrenches . I would recommend this product to those wanting extended battery time using portable tools .

This batteries is great . I have all the 20 Volt Dewalt tools and this battery is so much superior to the smaller one it is well worth the price . I recommend to anyone to upgrade to this higher capacity battery .

Save some cash and get the 2 pack . Just be sure you get the newer ones that have the life indicator on them . So nice to be able to see how much life is left in each one . No sense getting the older ones now that these are out.Battery life is amazing and they are much lighter than the older 18v version . A must for anyone needing new or more batteries for the 20v system .
have the entire line of dewalt 18v battery tools and am currently upgrading to the 20v . These batteries seem to have the same quality as the 18v li-ion but I love the new slide design .

Received 2 of these in the DCK590L2 20-Volt MAX Li-Ion 5-Tool Combo Kit I got and am highly impressed . So impressed that I bought 3 more . This dual pack and a single . Although technically this is really an 18 volt battery , it 's performance is much better than the 18 volt ni-cad batteries in my old Dewalt tools . Not only is runtime enhanced , it 's also much lighter and I love the new slide attachment vs the older clip attachments . It holds much better.I 've used this battery on pretty much every tool in the kit and am continually impressed . For instance , when in use on the Impact Driver , I was able to drive 100+ screws into hard wood before needing a charge . Using the drill , I was able to drill several holes for 1/2 '' x 2-3/4 '' Wedge Anchors , then drill 6 holes in a steel car frame and still had battery left over . The saws , while harder on the battery , were still able to be used to cut several pieces of timber for a outside deck.Dewalt definitely has a winner with the new 20 Volt Max line . I just really do n't like the trend all tool manufacturers are taking with the `` Max '' ratings . Reminds me too much of car audio . But this does n't really matter as long as the tools/batteries perform and these definitely do.I will say , however , these are quite pricey if bought by themselves . But DeWalt is n't alone with it 's battery pricing . Most of the `` contractor-grade '' tool makers tend to get a bit crazy with battery pricing .

It 's a nice product and being a lifelong DeWalt consumer , I can say that these batteries are 100 times better and more efficient than the old XRP batteries . I built an entire 10 x 15 shed with just over 1 battery charge . Awesome .
Ordered these for my husband for Christmas . He loves all things Dewalt ! They are excellent quality and will be very useful .

Bought them used , but they were still sealed in the original retail package . GREAT ! As far as the battery . Noticebale difference from the 1.5amp batteries that come with your puchase of the drill . I do n't understand why they do , i understand marketing , but that underminds the integrity of their product . Built tough to last weak ? I spent over $ 300 for the new 20volt drill/driver . Using a inch paddle bit on the impact driver , made about 6 holes in 2x4 lumber , before a noticeable change in performance fromt he 1.5amp stock battery . Im a little disappointed in dewalt , because here i am spending more money to get something i should have had to begin with ! There is no reason for 1.5amp battery for dewalt products . NO REASON ! I am paying for quality , not below average quality . Thats my beef with dewalt , but needs to be said . Wish these 3.0amp 20volt batteries came stock , would have been happier with more money in my pocket ! Plus side , i now have four batteries , but one charger !

I have owned DeWalt tools for over 30 years . Started out with the 9 volt systems and worked my way up to the 18 volt . I had no problem selling all my older 18 volt tools and went to the 20 Volt Max Li-Ion system . These batteries are some much better and lighter weight and smaller in size . I have noticed they last much longer between charges than the old 18 volt batteries and only time will tell about the longevity . My biggest complaint with the old batteries was after a few years they get to where they do n't take a charge and you have to buy new ones every 2-4 years . For someone who does n't use them very often that is disappointing . I used mine off and on with various projects that I would do where I use them alot and then not at all for awhile . I think they have got it right with the lithium it is just too bad they cost so much more but if they have the longevity then it will be worth it.Also I have had to use DeWalt 's warranty recently and have nothing but praise for the way the company handled replacing a battery of mine with-in the warranty period .

My husband has the tools that this rechargeable battery is used for , and he loves having two that he can switch back and forth . He always has one charging while using the other . This is a replacement for one that someone stole , so my husband is apparently not the only one who likes them .
Get set with tons of power . Makes short work of anything . Really compact yet powerful . Can not think about anything bad about it .
this came as an extra for a dewalt drill kit i bought a long time ago , they still hold charge , very please with their performnce !

These batteries really do hold their charge and perform really well , of course nothing compared to the new XR lineup by Dewalt but it 's handled everything I 've thrown at it around the house and I ca n't complain . I do n't always use my drill and only charge the batteries when they get low . Batteries hold strong even after months of not being used . My original review is below , and while it 's an awesome deal if you can get this extra in a kit ; the batteries themselves are pretty awesome too especially with a Dewalt 3 year Warranty.When I bought myDeWalt DCK280C2 20-Volt Max Li-Ion 1.5 Ah Compact Drill and Impact Driver Combo Kit , this was included for free . It really helped to offset the $ 300 price tag of the combo since the battery itself is $ 75 . I really like the design and lightweight of these smaller 1.5 Ah batteries though . They last a while , charge fast , three year warranty and simply stand up to the Dewalt name .

The re-designed clip of this lithium ion battery is awesome , and long overdue.It fits Dewalts new 20 volt 1 1/2 ah drill and impact driver , DCK280C2.The same set and design also comes in a 20 volt 3 ah combo.Some of Dewalt 's drill designs have been awkward to use.Such as , you ca n't reach the forward/reverse button with the thumbof the same hand thats holding the drill.And the buttons of the Dewalt traditional style battery pack requirea long reach by your thumb and middle finger to reach some hard to press buttons.Both of those issues have been addressed.Now when you hold the drill , the forward/reverse button is at thumbs reach.And this battery has one easy to press buttom on the front of the batterythat releases the clip , and the battery slides out.Now this is a smooth operation ! The lithium ion 20v charges in 15 to 30 min . depending how low the battery is .

I got this free as a combo with my drill set . Having three of these batteries is kind of pointless unless you are on a job with no charging . Last a long time under heavy use and store the charge as long as needed .

I bought 2 of these batteries and they work great . I use them primarily with my impact driver and it really makes for a lightweight and powerful combination . They work equally well in my drill driver . If you plan to use them in the hand saw I would recommend buying the 3.0 Ah batteries as these will allow for more cuts between charging . A great battery I would highly recommend .

Thought this book would be chock full of great projects for use with my Kreg Jig , instead , it 's chock full of ugly projects . On the other hand , for someone with little or no experience in building , this book is well written with some right to the point info to get a beginner started .

This light is useless for reading in bed next to someone . Even the one bulb lights up the entire room and blinds you with the reflective light from the book/kindle . It 's going to be great for camping , ghost hunting and the like , but you have to put a cover over it to read by . Maybe I should have read the `` MIGHTY '' part of the Mighty Bright .

These seem abnormally sized for the type of fixture they 're supposed to be mounted in . I had to manually clip the prongs to fit all the fixtures I tried them in . Seeing as how they 're branded for a G8 base you 'd think they 'd fit in G8 bulb sockets ... But , they were fixable with some elbow grease .
These burn out really fast . I buy them because they 're cheap and it 's more cost effective to change the bulbs all the time , but some of them last like 3-4 weeks .
Two bulb legs broke off two of them , as I was soldering them into the board . Ridiculous . Other than that , the remainder worked fine .

I have two of these lights . One works better than the other . Neither is a good asNewhouse Lighting NHCLP-LED-BLK 3-watt Energy-efficient Clamp LED Lamp , Black , which is also available at Amazon for a few dollars more . The problems with this lamp : The clamps do n't hold well . I had to try several different locations before I got the lamp to stay where I wanted it.The gooseneck is too flimsy . It is hard to keep the light where you want it.The LED light is a bit harsh in a dark room where this is the only light and you are reading . ( Is n't that what this is for ? ) The lamp also shares a common problem with many devices like this . The transformer that converts household current into the low voltage used by the LEDs is at the very end of the power cord . When you plug it into the power outlet , it blocks not only the one you plug it into , but the one next to it . I had to use a power strip to plug in two lamps , and lost four spaces instead of two . There is an alternative design , putting the transformer in the middle of the cord , that avoids this problem . Maybe that costs more , and price seems to be the major differentiation between different products like this.Do yourself a favor and get the Newhouse Lamp instead of this one .

I purchased this for my son to use while hes doing his school work and reading in bed . The good thing is that he can use it on his desk and his bed via the headboard . The arch neck sometimes just falls so it doesnt hold that arch for long periods of time could be cheaply made . Another issue that we noticed was that the light would get hot , equivalent to an incandescent . I purchased this because it was LED and it seemed like it was durable . I think it should be in the 15 dollar range or less , not worth over that ... .
I really liked this until it failed.If it had lasted more than a few weeks , I would have bought a carton of them .

My desk lamp was a bust . Imagine my surprise when shopping Amazon for a new one to find the same IKEA lamp that went bust for me with a lot of reviewers experiencing the same problem I had . I thought I had a bad lamp and waited too long to return it but evidently , the problem with the cord is an IKEA design issue.I loved this lamp -- as long as it worked . It has a weighted base , very flexible neck and nice bright LED light on a small head . But it was n't too long after using it that the bulb started to dim . Initially , if you toggled the switch , it would brighten back up.But eventually , there was nothing that could be done to find that sweet spot . I tried taking the switch apart to see if it was wired badly but the switch is glued together and could n't be taken apart.So now I have a lamp that I love in style and functionality , that does n't work , and I 'm having trouble finding a reasonably priced replacement that matches up to the size/style . Bummer . I agree , IKEA should be recalling this since so many are having the same trouble .

Porter Cable has a design flaw with the trigger locking switch . To use this in a router table , your must lock the trigger on and use a switch located on top of the router to turn it on . The problem is the switch lock breaks easily and the router will not function properly . I found this out the first time I used it in my table and sent it away to be fixed . After the fix , the repair lasted 20 minutes . I am now looking for another router to use in my table . I will only use the 7529 for hand held applications where I constantly hold down the trigger myself . Porter Cable should have a recall on this . I am not the only person with this problem . I posted my problem on a tool chat room and other woodworkers shared the same story . If you want to use this router for a router table , get another router . Save yourself the trouble .

I bought this router shortly after it was introduced thinking it was the next best thing since sliced bread . Man was I wrong ! For handheld use , it is stiff , cumbersome , and unbalanced . It 's worse in a router table , which was the main reason I bought it . I thought the second power switch would be handy for table use , except you have to lock the handle switch in the on position . And in order to do that , I had to tape mine just so the switch would lock into place . The height adjustment is a pain to work with . Overall , this is one of the worse routers I have used . If you want a router for a router table , spend the extra money and step up to a 3 HP router

I could not believe that the PC teck said that plunge routers all have play in the shaft . The right side has such play that you can tilt the router base by applying pressure to one side even when locked and he said this is normal ! I have a RE600 Ryobi that is solid in all positions . I tested the DeWalt621 and with one post it was solid . The depth adjustment is also very hard to set , you have to turn it many revolutions to get it to adjust . The dust shield falls off easily . I returned it after one day .

I was very disappointed with Porter Cable . The plunge mechanism sticks , the on button is hard to lock on for router table use , the depth gauge is extremely hard to use , and it is not compatible with most after-market accessories . Mine is sitting on a shelf . In its place is a DeWalt 621 plunge router . It is lighter , has a much better depth gauge and is just better all around . I love my DeWalt 621 . I wish I had bought it first .

I prefer brass . The Porter Cable guides are fine , they install easily , center easily , and perform flawlessly , , Most of the time . Just once in a while though , they fail completely . Steel , no matter how you protect it , will eventually corrode . Mine turned white and rusted , not all over , but on one side or the other . My guides often get removed from the case and hauled out to the job-sites while attached to the router . Early , foggy mornings and those sudden summer-time cloud bursts , expose my tools to far more of the elements than I like . So maybe , , it 's my fault . But brass just has n't let me down yet.Search `` brass template guide set '' and be amazed at the difference in price and the fact of the quality of these `` no-brand '' guides . Occasionally you may need to shine them up a little , but being solid brass , that 's not a big problem . I 've used both steel and brass on door hinge templates , dovetail templates , stair tread templates and strike plate templates . Brass just slides easier , smoother . On dovetail templates , especially plastic and soft aluminum the brass guides show less wear on the surfaces that the guides contact.I 'm sorry P.C . , , , I ca n't recommend these guides.I saw a review with a problem , the steel guides were too long and reached past the bottom of the dovetail template . With brass you can simply file the guide down to size to get the right length . Simple .

Porter Cable 42000 Template Guide KitI 've had a 42000 template guide kit since the mid 1990 's . The set works OK , but my advice is to buy another brand . The P/C kit comes in a cheap & fragile hard plastic case that must have cost all of ten cents to make and the components are held in place with inexpensive cardboard separators . In addition , after a dozen years or so , every component in my set had corroded terribly -- the metal looked similar to very old aluminum storm windows , pits and all . It 's not clear why this happened , since they 've never been outside the basement workshop , and no other tools corroded . The corrosion caused significant resistance when screwing on the lock-nuts . Steel wool reduced the roughness of the corrosion , but the pieces still look dreadful.The three largest guides in the P/C set are too long for numerous dovetail jigs , such as the Leigh jig . It 's possible to modify them to work with these jigs , by hack-sawing the excess length off the offending guides , flatten the cut end on a grinder and sanding the edge smooth . A no-cost approach.If you want steel guides , the Milwaukee 's 49-54-0700 set comes with a nice case , and the steel finish looks a whole lot better than P/C 's . Unfortunately , the three largest guides in the Milwaukee set are also too long for many dovetail jigsIn any case , brass is a better material for guides than steel , because brass is easier on a rotating router bit if it ever touches a guide . Once , near a day 's end of routing doors for hinges , my template 's locking ring came loose , allowing the guide to touch the spinning bit , and the locking ring to rub against the router-bit lock nut . Since the guide and ring were brass , no noticeable damage to the bit or router occurred . Had I been using any steel template with a steel locking ring , the bit or router could have been damaged . Try `` brass router template '' via Goggle - and buy a kit made of solid brass , in a decent case , for less money than this set . Also check out the Woodstock International H3134 Brass Bushing set at Amazon .

I have other Porter Cable products that work well . The quality & design of this edge guide shocked me . It could have easily had more than an additional 2 '' of travel with a simple design change . Or you could shorten the beam by 2 '' and have the same usable travel with a design change . The pins that adapt it to the router are .014 '' under size and the spread between the mounting holes on the router are .025 '' more on the base than on the pin location on the edge guide .
